Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WK6-GH61-JCS0-D011-00000-00New technology needs to be regulated by governments2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:15ZLexisNexisCOMMENTPg. 29New technology needs to be regulated by governmentsCHUKA UMUNNA

The mind boggles at the technology we are now using, which a few years ago we would very much have associated with science fiction and not reality. It is now part of everyday life and developing at such a speed that legislators and governments are struggling to keep up.

We have just started using a Google Home device in the Umunna household. It's a smart speaker similar to Amazon Alexa that answers your questions, gets the news, plays songs, and enables you to control other apps, (like Spotify), hands free, using your own voice. We weren't really following yesterday's Wimbledon men's final so during the match I asked Google Home and it told me what the current score was.

According to a report from this January, almost a quarter (21 per cent) of adults in the US now own a smart speaker with the figures rising, and here in the UK we seem to be following the same trend. At the very least, policymakers need to be consistent in their approach to the ever increasing tech usage - but this is not the case at present.

One example is the US authorities. On the one hand, they seem keen to ensure that the enormous tech companies play by the rules and contribute to the common good. So at the end of last week the US Federal Trade Commission (which performs much the same functions as the UK's Consumer and Markets Authority) reportedly approved a $5bn (£4bn) settlement with Facebook over allegations that the latter had inappropriately shared information belonging to 87 million users with the now defunct Cambridge Analytica political consulting firm.

On the other hand, in a knee-jerk response coloured by economic nationalism, Donald Trump has threatened to hit French goods with extra tariffs in retaliation for the French government announcing last week the imposition of a 3 per cent levy on large, mostly US, digital companies' local revenues.

President Emmanuel Macron's administration in Paris is of the view that the tech companies are paying little or no tax. The French tech tax will apply to tech companies with global sales of over Euro 750m (£673m) which make more than Euro 25m in France.

The advent of new technologies, the rise of automation, artificial intelligence and digitisation has brought many benefits, facilitating better and more efficient methods of communication, knowledge acquisition, working, shopping, spending our leisure time, travelling and generally organising our lives. It has the potential to revolutionise public services.

But the advent of the new super-tech platforms in particular has concentrated power and wealth in the hands of a small number of people, new technologies are being used to facilitate abuse, crime and terrorism and to enable foreign powers to challenge our democratic processes and national security. One need only look at the increasing amount of police time and resources taken up with dealing with cybercrime and online fraud to see the downside.

Vast quantities of our personal data is now held by others, not necessarily within our control, and public policy and legal frameworks are struggling to keep pace. We cannot stand idly by and not intervene in the public interest to address these problems.

Labour's shadow chancellor John McDonnell has talked about Labour's answer to all of this being "socialism with an iPad", meaning making Britain a leading power in technology. It's a good sound bite but the ideological dogma of yesteryear can't provide a comprehensive route map to the solutions to these very modern of issues.

The old, left-right fulcrum, around which politics revolved in the 20th century, is not an appropriate prism through which to view these very 21st century challenges. We want our data privacy respected as a core property right - a right-wing proposition - but to get the best rewards from the data revolution we need universal access to data, public platforms, and high accountability and transparency - left-wing propositions. It follows that we shouldn't pretend the answers will exclusively come from either ideological predisposition. So what should our approach be in ensuring these new technologies are used for the common good at home and abroad?

Britain needs a sophisticated, multitrack approach. The first track must be about making the most of the opportunities these technologies present in the UK. That means using all the levers of government to encourage the take-up and adoption of them which will help massively increase UK productivity, necessary to facilitate higher wages.

In addition, this will help ensure we create new jobs in this country to replace those displaced by automation and technological advance. Reindustrialising those areas which have been deindustrialised over time with these new industries must be a priority.

The second track should focus on using the new technologies to improve public service delivery. They can help accelerate and optimise administrative processes and improve citizens' experience of various services which can often be slow and inefficient. The efficiency gains will also save the Exchequer a lot of money which could be better used in other ways.

The third track must be about setting the right limits on these new technologies. They carry risks which are increasingly a focus of public debate: invasion of privacy, bullying or monopolistic behaviour by digital giants, misuse of personal data, tax evasion by firms with "intangible" profits, reckless testing and commercialisation of new technologies like driverless cars and private drones, the harnessing of such technologies by security threats, like criminals and terrorists, and geopolitical challengers, like China, which is increasingly integrating its AI strategies with its foreign policy.

The final track should address ownership and equality because too many of the rewards of these new technologies accrue to a relatively small number of individuals, exacerbating inequalities. New ownership structures must be developed to ensure greater distribution of the benefits - both to workers and wider society.

Our goal must be a constantly evolving body of democratised and repurposed regulation that tracks the realities of new technologies as they emerge and are applied, and starts from the principle that citizens, not governments or firms, should have the most power.

President Macron gets this. It is quite clear that Trump with his narrow nationalism does not. If the big tech companies are all made to pay their fair share and abide by the rules, all peoples and their governments - including Trump's - will benefit.

Chuka Umunna is the Liberal Democrat MP for Streatham

urn:contentItem:60G7-H9H1-F03R-N2VG-00000-00New text messages show Kevin Systrom worried about Mark Zuckerberg going into 'destroy mode' if he didn't sell to Facebook2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisNew text messages show Kevin Systrom worried about Mark Zuckerberg going into 'destroy mode' if he didn't sell to FacebookTyler Sonnemaker

Jul 29, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom worried that Mark Zuckerberg would go into "destroy mode" if he didn't sell the company to Facebook, according to records of his text messages[1].Instagram investor Matt Cohler warned that Zuckerberg would "go harder into destroy mode" if Instagram turned down the acquisition offer.The exchange was published by the House Judiciary Committee[2] as part of its historic antitrust hearing[3] Wednesday where Zuckerberg faced questions over Facebook's purchases of competitors.Regulators didn't challenge the Instagram acquisition at the time, but the deal has since drawn scrutiny from both regulators and politicians who say it constituted anti-competitive behavior.Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[4]. Mark Zuckerberg spent Wednesday trying to persuade lawmakers that Facebook's acquisitions and cloning of competitors' products and features haven't amounted to monopolistic behavior[5], and that it has plenty of competition[6].But when Zuckerberg first expressed interest in buying Instagram in 2012, cofounder Kevin Systrom didn't appear confident about what would happen if he opted to remain independent."Will [Zuckerberg] go into destroy mode if I say no [to an acquisition deal]?" Systrom asked in a message to Benchmark Capital's Matt Cohler, according to documents published by the House Judiciary Committee[7] as part of its antitrust hearing on Wednesday."Probably," replied Cohler, an early Facebook employee-turned-VC who had invested in Instagram and was on its board of directors.Cohler also warned that Zuckerberg was unlikely to be deterred by the fact that Instagram was keen on raising additional startup funding."He'll go harder into destroy mode," Cohler told Systrom.The names in the text transcript are redacted, but the committee's website[8] identifies the two participants in the conversation as Systrom and Cohler.

"Mark doesn't react emotionally, he reacts based on competition" Systrom and Cohler went on to strategize around how to best respond to Zuckerberg's probe, weighing options like downplaying Instagram's strength and saying the product wouldn't be a good fit or able to succeed within Facebook.But two things they seemed to agree on: Zuckerberg was most worried about Instagram getting bought up by Twitter, and they were worried about Zuckerberg trying to crush Instagram if they refused to sell."If i make the 'leave instagram alone for Facebook's sake' argument, [Zuckerberg] will conclude that it's best to crush instagram," Cohler said, implying that they wouldn't be able to fend off Facebook just by floating the possibility of selling to Twitter.Ultimately, Systrom and Cohler concluded during the text exchange that Instagram needed to keep raising money and they needed to convince Zuckerberg that they weren't a threat to Facebook."Mark doesn't react emotionally, he reacts based on competition," Systrom said, "that's why i think signaling no competition is good.""Bottom line I don't think we'll ever escape the wrath of mark," he added. "It just depends how long we avoid it."Facebook eventually got its way just two months after the exchange, buying Instagram for $1 billion[9] in April 2012. The price tag seemed massive at the time, but Instagram reportedly brought in $20 billion in revenue[10] for Facebook last year alone and has the second-most number of monthly users in the US, according to eMarketer[11].Facebook's acquisition of Instagram has since come under scrutiny from regulators and politicians who argue it amounted to anti-competitive practices. Zuckerberg faced multiple questions on the topic Wednesday, and argued that Facebook still faces lots of competition."The most popular messaging service in the US is iMessage," Zuckerberg told lawmakers. "The fastest-growing app is TikTok. The most popular app for video is YouTube. The fastest growing ads platform is Amazon. The largest ads platform is Google. And for every dollar spent on advertising in the US, less than 10 cents is spent with us."Still, the committee obtained large numbers of documents from Facebook and others companies as part of its antitrust investigation, including emails where Zuckerberg said he viewed Instagram as a significant threat to Facebook's business before acquiring it[12]. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TT4-FGF1-J9XT-P2YS-00000-00New TLT Report: Finance leaders race to unlock Open Banking potential2018-11-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisNew TLT Report: Finance leaders race to unlock Open Banking potential

Hambridge: Business Money has issued the following news release: Open Banking is one of the most radical changes in the recent history of financial services and has already dramatically impacted the investment decisions of financial services companies, according to a new report (Opportunity Knocks) published today by UK law firm TLT. The new research – based on survey responses from 130 senior decision makers representing a diverse range of financial companies across the UK – reports that a vast majority (84%) are investing in Open Banking products and services. 44% are also considering launching new products or services to improve the Open Banking experience for customers. A significant majority (77%) say Open Banking and PSD2 is one of the most radical changes in recent history for financial services, with 35% saying they strongly agree.

However, more than half (53%) of respondents say the industry has found it difficult to adapt to these new regulations. Despite high levels of enthusiasm and investment, many financial services firms – both banks and non-banks such as fintechs and payment services providers – are struggling to formulate and implement comprehensive strategies to deal with Open Banking. Two thirds (62%) say they do not have a comprehensive strategy in place and 13% have no investment strategy at all. Looming competitive threats, including from big tech Financial services companies are also clearly worried about competitive threats in the wake of the implementation of Open Banking, the research finds. In particular, banks see ‘big tech’ companies – such as Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple – as the biggest perceived competitive threat in the Open Banking space (63%). 45% of non-banks agree. Other threats come from within the existing ecosystem of banks, challengers and fintechs. Two thirds (66%) of respondents believe the market will ultimately become more consolidated with larger banks and corporates buying fintech businesses and smaller banks to keep pace with the level of innovation and speed of product development required to make a success of Open Banking. Even amidst myriad challenges and competitive threats, respondents suggest Open Banking is on track to achieve the aspirations of the industry's regulators. More than two-thirds say that Open Banking, once fully implemented, will bring greater innovation to the industry (70%) and more choice for customers (65%), while half agree it will enable greater customer control of banking data and services (50%) and easier industry collaboration (48%). Overall, a large majority (72%) believe that Open Banking has been a positive step forward for the industry. David Gardner, partner in the financial services team at TLT, commented: "Our research reveals the true scale of disruption that financial services companies are grappling with, alongside the opportunities that these far-reaching changes have created – provided that companies can keep up with the pace of change. It is encouraging to see that the vast majority of respondents hold Open Banking up as a positive initiative and – despite the challenges with defining a clear Open Banking strategy – the industry is not standing still. "Innovation is happening all the time as more participants define their strategy and find new ways to collaborate,, which is creating a huge sense of anticipation in the market. The race is on for every participant to identify their position and launch a "killer app" or product to capture that opportunity. Open Banking will open up the market to new participants and continue to drive disruption for all. This could result in a more polarised market, split between niche offerings and financial services platforms, and between those who embrace agile transformation and those that are more reactive and slower to adapt. "There are considerable challenges for existing players and new entrants – from complying with regulatory technical standards to identifying market opportunities and potential partnerships and making sure that customer data is adequately protected. Customer confidence and trust must be a major area of focus in order to realise the potential benefits that Open Banking can deliver. Would-be Open Banking champions need to consider their position, their partners and their strategy carefully, but make sure they can act and react quickly enough to take full advantage, before someone else does."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W7K-YFB1-JCSH-3464-00000-00New tools, stiffer penalties needed to police big tech companies, says competition watchdog2019-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:15ZLexisNexisNew tools, stiffer penalties needed to police big tech companies, says competition watchdogCBC News

The federal government should boost the penalties for anti-competitive behaviour to more effectively regulate tech giants and the digital economy, says Canada's competition watchdog.

"The maximum penalties for anti-competitive behaviour are, quite simply, not high enough in Canada, meaning we lack the teeth necessary to deter anti-competitive behaviour and promote compliance," Commissioner of Competition Matthew Boswell told an Ottawa forum on data and the digital economy Thursday.

Boswell's comments come as calls have been multiplying in the U.S. for the government to take anti-trust action to split up tech companies like Facebook because they have become too powerful.

Earlier this week, elected officials from a dozen countries were in Ottawa to grill representatives of some of the biggest tech giants on everything from their efforts to fight hate speech and harmful content on the internet to their business practices.

Trust issues

In an interview with CBC News, Boswell said his office has been getting complaints and launching investigations related to the digital economy.

"On the consumer side, we have seen lots of problems in terms of trust in the digital economy," he said. "We have pursued cases against multiple large corporations for false or misleading representations online.

"We have an ongoing case against Ticketmaster in terms of online pricing representations and we just resolved a case against Hudson's Bay for price representations, many of which were made online."

Boswell told the forum that Canada's competition law is "generally up to the task" of dealing with big data. However, he said, his office needs new tools to more effectively regulate the digital economy.

Boswell said his office lacks the power to conduct market studies, including the information-gathering abilities found in most developed jurisdictions. Canada is also the only major economy to have an "efficiencies defence" in competition cases "which can allow mergers that potentially hamper competition and which, some say, is particularly ill suited for the digital economy," he said.

Boswell said the federal Competition Bureau also has to improve the technology it uses to handle evidence needed to police the digital economy. The bureau's ongoing investigation of bread price-fixing by grocery stores has gathered 100 terabytes of data, requiring specialized tools to analyze and review the records.

To help deal with the challenges, the bureau has created a new position of chief digital enforcement officer to help position the bureau as one of the world's leading competition regulators in the digital economy, Boswell said.

Among the issues the bureau will be examining is whether data acts as a barrier, preventing other players from entering the marketplace.

Boswell said the bureau is also going to be more vigilant about monitoring the acquisition of small firms by big tech companies â€” particularly transactions that could affect competition. Flanked on the forum panel by representatives of competition regulators from the U.S. and the European Union, Boswell said laws have to change to allow competition regulators to be able to quickly obtain evidence located in other countries.

Sharing information over borders

"Because of jurisdictional issues and access to evidence, we need to think about new ways to share information and to share information very quickly across borders, in the public interest in multiple jurisdictions," he said. "We can no longer tolerate a world in which it takes months, if not years, for us to obtain information that is not situated in Canada but that's very relevant to conduct going on in Canada."

Boswell said countries have to work together to deal with the challenges of tech giants and the digital economy.

"The rapid rise of the borderless digital economy is a truly global phenomenon, which requires competition authorities to collaborate and cooperate on an almost daily basis. I believe that the best way to look at global conduct that may cause concern is by taking a globally-coordinated approach to enforcement."

Elizabeth Thompson can be reached at elizabeth.thompson@cbc.ca

urn:contentItem:5TYD-9001-DY0W-41F7-00000-00New Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In Art2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisNew Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In ArtLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, we are. Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much. We will see you in a little bit. Big day today. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, December 11th. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the EAST COAST. Stocks are extending gains right now, we are at the highs of the morning with a big rally underway. Dow Industrials set to open up this morning better than a hundred points, the S&P 500 is up 10, and the NASDAQ up 38 points, that's two-thirds of one percent higher this morning.

After a wild day yesterday on Wall Street, markets were volatile, climbing from the lowest to the end of the day in positive territory. Big rally toward the end of the day, taking the market off of the lows. The Dow had been down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May delayed the vote on the deal to leave the European Union. Then, by the close, as you can see, markets reversed course. Up 34 points at the close on the Dow.

Global markets this morning are also seeing a bit of a bounce, take a look at FT-100 up better than one percent, 69 points higher, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 71 points, one and a half percent higher, and the DAX Index in Germany also higher by one and a half percent, that's a hundred and fifty- seven points higher this morning. In Asia overnight, markets with little change, as you can see there, very fractional moves and mixed. Trade talks are moving forward. The U.S. and China holding a new round of negotiations last night. We have the very latest on where that stands.

And coming together, President Trump set to meet with House Minority Leader, Nancy Pelosi, and funding the border wall among top items on the agenda, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi will go to the White House. Democrats reportedly ready to offer to $1.3 billion for the wall, but that is the short of the President's $5 billion request. Google's turn on the hot seat today. CEO Sundar Pichai's headed to Capitol Hill today. He will testify before the House Judiciary Committee. FOX Business will bring you that live at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will take a look at what to expect from his testimony this morning.

Then Nirvana's Smells Like Teen Spirit losing its crown as the most streamed song from the 20th century. We'll tell you what tune knocked it off the top spot, all that coming up this morning. All those stories coming up. Joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, and Beyond Sport Global Ambassador, Fox News Contributor, John Layfield. It's great to see you this morning.

JOHN LAYFIELD FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR AND BEYOND SPORT GLOBAL AMBASSADOR: It's great to see you. Going to be a crazy week. With the Brexit, its potential government shutdown, this is going to be nuts.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Nice to see the green though in the market this morning, really. Positive reaction to some of this trade news and especially in Europe, all in the green after yesterday's Brexit.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see how it closes. The market's volatility has been just unreal.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. It's a market that's trading off headlines, that's trading off commentary, from somebody, anybody, everybody, coming out of the White House, and I think that that's going to be the case. Other than the Federal Reserve meeting in the month of December, that's really the only, like, hardcore piece of news that we have coming up that we -- that we know about.

BARTIROMO: We talked yesterday about the fact that the President of France, Macron, has not been seen in the face of all of these riots. We did hear from him yesterday, Dagen. What did do you think?

MCDOWELL: He is pledging tax cuts and minimum wage hikes to placate protesters, but, again, I want to point out that the -- kind of the kickoff to these yellow-vest protests was a gas tax hike to push his environmental agenda, and I think that that is an actually -- it's an honest move because that is what it does take if you want to broadly reduce emissions and push an environmentalist agenda. It's -- everybody bears the cost of it. That gas tax hike has completely gone away, but the protestors have still been out four weekends in a row so I -- I'm curious to see if this really does kind of soothe the unrest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because they say --

MCDOWELL: -- and the --

BARTIROMO: -- he's out of touch, which is the -- which is the criticism.

The S&P 500 up 30 points, better than one percent higher, NASDAQ up 98 points, that's 1-1/2 percent higher on the NASDAQ right now,

Similar story in Europe, we've got gains across the board. Take a look at the European indices with the FT-100 up two percent, 127 points higher on the FT. 101 points higher on the CAC Quarante, that's better than two percent. And the DAX Index in Germany up 228 points, 2.15 percent higher in Germany. Little action in Asian markets overnight, as you can see, it was a flat session overall and it was mixed.

President Trump has been tweeting this morning. He just tweeted on his Chief of Staff position, he says this, "Fake news has it purposely wrong. Many, over 10, are vying for and wanting the White House Chief of Staff position. Why wouldn't someone want one of the truly great and meaningful jobs in Washington. Please report news correctly." says the President, "Thank you."

Plus, Apple hitting the sales ban on older phones in China, the fallout for the company coming up, this morning. Apple shares are up 1-1/3 percent right now. And then, there's this, the bests of the bests, the list of the top large companies to work for. That list will be revealed this morning. Time Magazine announcing its "Person of the Year" for 2018. We will tell you who Time chose. That's also coming up this morning.

But first, our top story this half an hour, pushing to save the U.K. exit deal, Prime Minister Theresa May taking a trip across Europe postponing today's scheduled vote on Britain leaving the European Union. Ashley Webster has been live in London this week. He's got the very latest from the ground. Ashley, good morning to you.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, good morning to you, Maria. It was supposed to be the day today, the day the voted on Theresa May's deal, instead, the U.K. Prime Minister is off on a frantic round of diplomacy today, heading from one European capital to the other, hoping to persuade E.U. leaders to provide some concessions to her Brexit deal. Earlier this morning, she had breakfast with the Dutch Prime Minister, Mark Rutte, they apparently had useful dialogue. We understand what that means, nobody knows.

She then went on to Berlin to meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel. There was a bit of an embarrassing moment when Mrs. May's car showed up and was to be greeted by Angela Merkel and she couldn't get out of the car, the door was locked (AUDIO GAP) to unlock it. Embarrassing but perhaps an interesting analogy of her being trapped in her own Brexit deal right now.

And then later on today, she'll be heading to Brussels to meet with the President of the European Council Jean-Claude Juncker. Now, Juncker himself spoke to the E.U. parliament earlier today in Strasbourg, France and said very clearly that there is no renegotiating Mrs. May's Brexit deal. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEAN-CLAUDE JUNCKER, PRESIDENT, EUROPEAN COUNCIL: We have achieved is the best deal possible, it's the only deal possible. No room whatsoever for renegotiation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: No deal whatsoever, I think that's pretty clear as you can make it. We understand that the -- whatever deal that Mrs. May gets, she says it will be voted on back here in the Houses of Parliament before January 21st. And the clock is ticking, Maria, time running out. They have until March 29th to try and figure something out before the U.K. gets out of the European Union, and it could indeed look more and more like a hard Brexit.

Having said that, the sharks are circling around her job as well. Tory MPs, more MPs we understand have submitted letters calling for a vote of confidence in her, as the Conservative Party leader and then Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the opposition Labour Party is under pressure to call a vote of no confidence in the government. That hasn't happened yet, but certainly, Mrs. May under the gun, doing her best to come back from Europe with something, but at this point, it doesn't look like she's going to be able to achieve very much, Maria. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Ashley, thank you so much. We'll check back as news develops. Ashley Webster in London this morning.

I want to bring in John Browne, he is former member of Britain's Parliament. He's also Euro Pacific Capital --

JOHN BROWNE, FORMER MEMBER OF BRITAIN'S PARLIAMENT: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: -- Senior Economic Consultant. John, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us. Let me ask you right out.

BROWNE: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What's your reaction to what has taken place last 48 hours in London?

BROWNE: Well, it's the most embarrassing situation. It's -- the world is laughing at the British circus. After 13 months of squandered time, we have no deal. In fact, we have the deal that's worse than when we started. It's -- it looks like a joke but it's very, very serious. And it's very serious not just for Britain and Europe, but it's a large section of world trade with the second largest currency in the world, the European Union. So, if things go bad, it's going to be bad for a lot of the world. It's a very serious situation, but it's reached a sort of laughing stock.

And I get increasingly suspicious of Prime Minister May. I thought she was going to be honest and going for Brexit, but I look at this chaos, and I have to ask myself, is it just an accident or is it by intent? It looks to me now when she comes back with an impossible deal which is worse than when we started, that in a cricketing term, she's played the ball into the long grass, which means you -- when you're losing a match, you try to lose the ball so the match can't continue, and you end up with a draw. And so, I think --

BARTIROMO: So, what are you saying -- what are you saying, John? Are you saying she really doesn't in her heart of hearts want to leave -- she doesn't want to really leave the E.U.? Do you want to see a different prime minister in the U.K.?

BROWNE: Yes, she was, by her own admission, a remainer, she's a globalist. She doesn't like Brexit at all. And I think she's in league with the European Union to play this thing the long game so that the impossible situation, and gradually Brexit is renegotiated, negotiated and in fact, we'll be back where we started but worst off because we won't have a position on the board. And of course, I feel like a growing majority of conservative members of parliament that she must either tender her resignation or be replaced by the 1922 committee in a vote of conservative members of parliament. I think it's becoming urgent because I think she's doing the country great harm. This whole journey to Europe, to me, is a laughing matter, and it's made England look ridiculously and it's very, very embarrassing and extremely serious.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LAYFIELD: John, what is the most likely outcome going to happen? I've heard rumors -- it's John Layfield of New York -- I've heard rumors that the 48 letters have already been gathered. They've been gathered for some time waiting on a no confidence vote to do that the right time. Are we going to see -- if we do see a new prime minister, it's going to (INAUDIBLE) probably be a Conservative Party member? Are we going to see a hard Brexit, or is there a chance we're going to see another referendum because what you have right now as you have articulated is not what 17.4 million Brits voted for to begin with?

BROWNE: Exactly. Now, of course, you could get rid of the prime minister two ways: one is a vote of confidence in the floor of the House which would mean the fall of the government and probably, looking at the polls, Jeremy Corbyn is the next prime minister. Heaven forbid! But there are much neater way -- there are much neater ways for the conservative parliament -- members of parliament to vote her out as leader of the party. And so, still have a conservative leader. And hopefully, if that happened, and probably likely if it happened, it would be a pro Brexit prime minister, someone like Rees-Mogg or David Davis, or Boris Johnson, someone like that.

BARTIROMO: Well, meanwhile, the economy hangs in the balance. I mean, what kind of an impact does this all have on the U.K. economy?

BROWNE: Well, it's uncertainty. Nobody likes uncertainty. Businesses can't plan, and financial people have a very bad time, it's depressing on business and financials.

BARTIROMO: John, thanks much for joining us. We appreciate your insights. John Browne. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. As we've been reporting, Google's CEO Sundar Pichai is headed to Capitol Hill today where he will be questioned by the House Judiciary Committee. Earlier we heard from Jim Jordan on the committee. Joining us right now to weigh in is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney with more right now. Stu, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Maria, this is -- he is -- so, Sundar Pichai is one of the world's most powerful people. Google knows absolutely everything about you. And so, when he appears today, there's obviously questions of privacy. Google runs Gmail, somebody read my Gmail, because I got a call from India about a Minor League's medical problem that I have over the past couple of years. The callers suggested, oh, we can fix this. How did that person get that information? How somebody read my Gmail, my personal Gmail. And I'm not happy about it! That's a gross invasion of my privacy. Now, the deal is you get Gmail for free, free communications, whoop-de-do, but they can sell that information, and that information is available to third parties, and I don't like it. And I want to know what they're going to do about it. I don't know what you can do about it, but I'm not happy.

BARTIROMO: No.

VARNEY: And when it comes to censoring political views of conservatives when it comes to building a search engine in China which is subject to censorship and surveillance by the Chinese authorities, I think Google has got a problem. I think this is a very big deal. We may get a hint of what Congress might do to the Googles of this world later.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I agree with you. These are real issues, and these are issues that everybody gets touched by, whether it's privacy or the -- or the censoring of speech, so this is -- this is important. You think we'll see more regulation at some point?

VARNEY: Yes, but I don't know what kind of regulation it's going to be.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's what we're trying to understand better.

VARNEY: I mean, the real answer would be real competition, but I don't see how you get competition for a search engine which has got, what, 80 percent of the market.

BARTIROMO: Well, Google has 90 percent --

VARNEY: 90 percent. Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- of the market for search. Stu, I know you'll have a lot more and we're going to come to you and see the hearing, live, happening at 10:00 a.m. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins at the top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. So, join Stuart and his guests, coming up. And then, that is when you will see the hearing where Sundar Pichai is to speak at 10:00 a.m.

But first, the best places to work, we're revealing which company took the top spot this year right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Apple hit with a sales ban in China. Gerri Willis on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange looking at that and what's expected to be a strong rally this morning, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. A big turnaround in sentiment playing off of what we saw yesterday here. Apple shares also enjoying, they're bumped up as well after a Chinese court ordered the iPhone maker to stop selling older model iPhones including the X, the 8, the 7, and the 6. Apple saying this in response, "Qualcomm's effort to ban our products is another desperate move by a company whose illegal practices are under investigation by regulators. The significance of this first I.P. court decision that seeks to curtail iPhone sales." Meanwhile, Pegatron, an iPhone assembler is exempted from this. Interesting Taiwan-based company.

I want to get quickly here to the companies of the best places to work. Starting with number five, Aflac, HubSpot, T-Mobile, number two, Google, and this list put up by comparably. It's a comp Web site. Google number two despite the fact that there was a walkout of employees over issues of sexual harassment. Numbers one on this list Costco, they say the benefits for workers at Costco are very good, indeed. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: Wow. OK. So, Costco, the best place to work. Costco, followed by Google, T-Mobile, HubSpot, and Aflac. Thank you so much, Gerri. Great list there. We'll take a short break.

Then, when we come back, Time Magazine's "Person of the Year." We'll discuss who was the most influential in 2018. Also, I went to see Bocelli last night. I want to tell you all about it. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Welcome back. Well, the list is out, Time Magazine makes it official, the "2018 Person of the Year", the Guardians, journalist who have been targeted for their work. There are four covers, one features Jamal Khashoggi, the murdered Washington Post columnist, another highlights Maria Ressa, a Philippine journalist. The third features two Reuters journalists who were arrested a year ago for their reporting on Muslims, and the final cover shows the staff of the Capital Gazette. Their office, you know, was the target of a shooting earlier this year. That is the Time Magazine Person of the Year. Reaction?

MCDOWELL: Meaningful and it expresses American values. And the value of the first amendment, and how journalist to break news, put their lives on the line very often. So, I give -- I give kudos to Time for this very much.

BARTIROMO: Yes, this was a great idea to do this, and they should be heralded and cherished for their important work.

Meanwhile, what a night last night. I know I've been telling you all about what I did last night. I went to see Italian songwriter and tenor Andrea Bocelli perform in New York City. It was a private concert at the Columbus Citizens Foundation. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It was such a memorable night. I love Andrea Bocelli. I took my sister and next to me is the wife of Andrea Bocelli, Veronica. The -- and there's Lidia Bastianich, as well, along with myself and my sister. We talked about the Andrea Bocelli Foundation which raises money for underprivileged people. As the Columbus Foundation brought together the Andrea Bocelli Foundation. Thank you to both. It was fun.

MCDOWELL: Jealous.

(LAUGHTER)

END

urn:contentItem:5WMY-CG41-JBHT-D413-00000-00New Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In Art2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisNew Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In ArtLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, we are. Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much. We will see you in a little bit. Big day today. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, December 11th. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the EAST COAST. Stocks are extending gains right now, we are at the highs of the morning with a big rally underway. Dow Industrials set to open up this morning better than a hundred points, the S&P 500 is up 10, and the NASDAQ up 38 points, that's two-thirds of one percent higher this morning.

After a wild day yesterday on Wall Street, markets were volatile, climbing from the lowest to the end of the day in positive territory. Big rally toward the end of the day, taking the market off of the lows. The Dow had been down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May delayed the vote on the deal to leave the European Union. Then, by the close, as you can see, markets reversed course. Up 34 points at the close on the Dow.

Global markets this morning are also seeing a bit of a bounce, take a look at FT-100 up better than one percent, 69 points higher, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 71 points, one and a half percent higher, and the DAX Index in Germany also higher by one and a half percent, that's a hundred and fifty- seven points higher this morning. In Asia overnight, markets with little change, as you can see there, very fractional moves and mixed. Trade talks are moving forward. The U.S. and China holding a new round of negotiations last night. We have the very latest on where that stands.

And coming together, President Trump set to meet with House Minority Leader, Nancy Pelosi, and funding the border wall among top items on the agenda, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi will go to the White House. Democrats reportedly ready to offer to $1.3 billion for the wall, but that is the short of the President's $5 billion request. Google's turn on the hot seat today. CEO Sundar Pichai's headed to Capitol Hill today. He will testify before the House Judiciary Committee. FOX Business will bring you that live at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will take a look at what to expect from his testimony this morning.

Then Nirvana's Smells Like Teen Spirit losing its crown as the most streamed song from the 20th century. We'll tell you what tune knocked it off the top spot, all that coming up this morning. All those stories coming up. Joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, and Beyond Sport Global Ambassador, Fox News Contributor, John Layfield. It's great to see you this morning.

JOHN LAYFIELD FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR AND BEYOND SPORT GLOBAL AMBASSADOR: It's great to see you. Going to be a crazy week. With the Brexit, its potential government shutdown, this is going to be nuts.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Nice to see the green though in the market this morning, really. Positive reaction to some of this trade news and especially in Europe, all in the green after yesterday's Brexit.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see how it closes. The market's volatility has been just unreal.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. It's a market that's trading off headlines, that's trading off commentary, from somebody, anybody, everybody, coming out of the White House, and I think that that's going to be the case. Other than the Federal Reserve meeting in the month of December, that's really the only, like, hardcore piece of news that we have coming up that we -- that we know about.

BARTIROMO: We talked yesterday about the fact that the President of France, Macron, has not been seen in the face of all of these riots. We did hear from him yesterday, Dagen. What did do you think?

MCDOWELL: He is pledging tax cuts and minimum wage hikes to placate protesters, but, again, I want to point out that the -- kind of the kickoff to these yellow-vest protests was a gas tax hike to push his environmental agenda, and I think that that is an actually -- it's an honest move because that is what it does take if you want to broadly reduce emissions and push an environmentalist agenda. It's -- everybody bears the cost of it. That gas tax hike has completely gone away, but the protestors have still been out four weekends in a row so I -- I'm curious to see if this really does kind of soothe the unrest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because they say --

MCDOWELL: -- and the --

BARTIROMO: -- he's out of touch, which is the -- which is the criticism.

MCDOWELL: All right. But I need to give Nile Gardiner credit.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: I used the phrase "swanning about the globe while (INAUDIBLE) capital city is burning. Nile used that phrase over the weekend. So, credit to Nile on that.

BARTIROMO: And he was great when he joined us to --

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: -- navigate all of this. We got a big show this morning. Coming up, joining the conversation this morning, Ohio Congressman and House Judiciary Committee Member, Jim Jordan is here. We're going to talk with the Congressman about that Google hearing among other things. Plus Jim Comey, lots to talk about with Jim Jordan. Michigan Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member, Debbie Dingell, is with us this morning. Congresswoman Dingell has a lot to say about General Motors. Plus the Chairman and CEO of Motorola Solutions, Greg Brown, is with us this morning. He's turned that company around.

And Former British Parliament Member Euro Pacific Capital Senior Economic Consultant, John Browne, is here as well. Plus FOX News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane joins us as well. Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big three hours coming up. We kick it off right here with this top story, and that is all of these swings in the market. Checking Futures right now, we're expecting a pretty strong opening for today's trading. Dow Industrials right now up a hundred and twelve points, a half a percent higher after a wild day yesterday when the Dow slid to session lows down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May announced a delay of the exit vote, Britain leaving European Union.

But look at that chart, markets reverse in course, as the session wore on and as you can see, after the lows hit at about 11:15 a.m. in the morning, things slowly but surely came back only to end higher. When we were down at 11:15 market better than 500 points. Market was briefly in correction territory down 20 percent from the high, that means. Joining us right now, CIO, EventShares CIO Ben Phillips. And Ben, it is good to have you on the program this morning.

BEN PHILLIPS, CIO, EVENTSHARES: Thanks for having me, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What a market. How are you doing with all this volatility?

PHILLIPS: Well, we've done some things in portfolio raise cash actually on the Fed pop. I guess that was a couple of Wednesdays ago. So, we had a big day up, markets were up about two percent. We actually raised cash to 17 percent in portfolio.

BARTIROMO: Oh, wow. Big number.

PHILLIPS: Yes. So, it was a meaningful move. You know, I think the thought was get a little more defensive. We were pretty skeptical on anything positive coming out of G20. And so after we actually saw that over the weekend, we started to look -- even get a little more defensive.

BARTIROMO: But longer term, has anything changed in terms of structural, you know, performance for this market? Look At the backdrop --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in terms of growth expectations, higher rates, has anything specifically changed that you really want to shift your allocation and hold it in cash and just like --

PHILLIPS: Well, I think we have to realize that we are late cycle, and there's going to be more late-cycle activity. The Fed is pumping the brakes and what that means is the rate-sensitive sectors are going to see some of that, you know, giveback and that's what we're seeing. I think it's normal to see this type of activity towards the end of the cycle as the Feds starts its heightening cycle. So, you know, they said don't fight the Fed for the past 10 years effectively, don't fight the Feds still, you know. They're tightening for a reason, that's going to have implications on markets.

BELL: One trend that we've seen though on these days, these mornings when you're up like this by a nice amount --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BELL: -- we've seen that pop, initial pop, sold into the end of the day and we end the day --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

BELL: -- at the lows, do you expect that today? When can that trend turn around?

PHILLIPS: Yes, you know, I hear the question. It's tough to call it a day-to-day move obviously.

BELL: Yes.

PHILLIPS: But I -- you know, I talked to people about a potential rally, you know, a Santa rally, or even a January rally, which is somewhat typical. People are looking to fade, looking to sell into it. So, I think that's going to be a trend we're going to see here. There's been a rotation that's occurred at the hedge funds where they've derisked. They've brought down leverage and now we're at a situation where they still have a little bit more to go, I think. It looks to me now when she comes back with an impossible deal which is worse than when we started, that in a cricketing term, she's played the ball into the long grass, which means you -- when you're losing a match, you try to lose the ball so the match can't continue, and you end up with a draw. And so, I think --

BARTIROMO: So, what are you saying -- what are you saying, John? Are you saying she really doesn't in her heart of hearts want to leave -- she doesn't want to really leave the E.U.? Do you want to see a different prime minister in the U.K.?

BROWNE: Yes, she was, by her own admission, a remainer, she's a globalist. She doesn't like Brexit at all. And I think she's in league with the European Union to play this thing the long game so that the impossible situation, and gradually Brexit is renegotiated, negotiated and in fact, we'll be back where we started but worst off because we won't have a position on the board. And of course, I feel like a growing majority of conservative members of parliament that she must either tender her resignation or be replaced by the 1922 committee in a vote of conservative members of parliament. I think it's becoming urgent because I think she's doing the country great harm. This whole journey to Europe, to me, is a laughing matter, and it's made England look ridiculously and it's very, very embarrassing and extremely serious.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LAYFIELD: John, what is the most likely outcome going to happen? I've heard rumors -- it's John Layfield of New York -- I've heard rumors that the 48 letters have already been gathered. They've been gathered for some time waiting on a no confidence vote to do that the right time. Are we going to see -- if we do see a new prime minister, it's going to (INAUDIBLE) probably be a Conservative Party member? Are we going to see a hard Brexit, or is there a chance we're going to see another referendum because what you have right now as you have articulated is not what 17.4 million Brits voted for to begin with?

BROWNE: Exactly. Now, of course, you could get rid of the prime minister two ways: one is a vote of confidence in the floor of the House which would mean the fall of the government and probably, looking at the polls, Jeremy Corbyn is the next prime minister. Heaven forbid! But there are much neater way -- there are much neater ways for the conservative parliament -- members of parliament to vote her out as leader of the party. And so, still have a conservative leader. And hopefully, if that happened, and probably likely if it happened, it would be a pro Brexit prime minister, someone like Rees-Mogg or David Davis, or Boris Johnson, someone like that.

BARTIROMO: Well, meanwhile, the economy hangs in the balance. I mean, what kind of an impact does this all have on the U.K. economy?

BROWNE: Well, it's uncertainty. Nobody likes uncertainty. Businesses can't plan, and financial people have a very bad time, it's depressing on business and financials.

BARTIROMO: John, thanks much for joining us. We appreciate your insights. John Browne. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. As we've been reporting, Google's CEO Sundar Pichai is headed to Capitol Hill today where he will be questioned by the House Judiciary Committee. Earlier we heard from Jim Jordan on the committee. Joining us right now to weigh in is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney with more right now. Stu, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Maria, this is -- he is -- so, Sundar Pichai is one of the world's most powerful people. Google knows absolutely everything about you. And so, when he appears today, there's obviously questions of privacy. Google runs Gmail, somebody read my Gmail, because I got a call from India about a Minor League's medical problem that I have over the past couple of years. The callers suggested, oh, we can fix this. How did that person get that information? How somebody read my Gmail, my personal Gmail. And I'm not happy about it! That's a gross invasion of my privacy. Now, the deal is you get Gmail for free, free communications, whoop-de-do, but they can sell that information, and that information is available to third parties, and I don't like it. And I want to know what they're going to do about it. I don't know what you can do about it, but I'm not happy.

BARTIROMO: No.

VARNEY: And when it comes to censoring political views of conservatives when it comes to building a search engine in China which is subject to censorship and surveillance by the Chinese authorities, I think Google has got a problem. I think this is a very big deal. We may get a hint of what Congress might do to the Googles of this world later.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I agree with you. These are real issues, and these are issues that everybody gets touched by, whether it's privacy or the -- or the censoring of speech, so this is -- this is important. You think we'll see more regulation at some point?

VARNEY: Yes, but I don't know what kind of regulation it's going to be.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's what we're trying to understand better.

VARNEY: I mean, the real answer would be real competition, but I don't see how you get competition for a search engine which has got, what, 80 percent of the market.

BARTIROMO: Well, Google has 90 percent --

VARNEY: 90 percent. Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- of the market for search. Stu, I know you'll have a lot more and we're going to come to you and see the hearing, live, happening at 10:00 a.m. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins at the top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. So, join Stuart and his guests, coming up. And then, that is when you will see the hearing where Sundar Pichai is to speak at 10:00 a.m.

But first, the best places to work, we're revealing which company took the top spot this year right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Apple hit with a sales ban in China. Gerri Willis on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange looking at that and what's expected to be a strong rally this morning, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. A big turnaround in sentiment playing off of what we saw yesterday here. Apple shares also enjoying, they're bumped up as well after a Chinese court ordered the iPhone maker to stop selling older model iPhones including the X, the 8, the 7, and the 6. Apple saying this in response, "Qualcomm's effort to ban our products is another desperate move by a company whose illegal practices are under investigation by regulators. The significance of this first I.P. court decision that seeks to curtail iPhone sales." Meanwhile, Pegatron, an iPhone assembler is exempted from this. Interesting Taiwan-based company.

I want to get quickly here to the companies of the best places to work. Starting with number five, Aflac, HubSpot, T-Mobile, number two, Google, and this list put up by comparably. It's a comp Web site. Google number two despite the fact that there was a walkout of employees over issues of sexual harassment. Numbers one on this list Costco, they say the benefits for workers at Costco are very good, indeed. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: Wow. OK. So, Costco, the best place to work. Costco, followed by Google, T-Mobile, HubSpot, and Aflac. Thank you so much, Gerri. Great list there. We'll take a short break.

Then, when we come back, Time Magazine's "Person of the Year." We'll discuss who was the most influential in 2018. Also, I went to see Bocelli last night. I want to tell you all about it. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Welcome back. Well, the list is out, Time Magazine makes it official, the "2018 Person of the Year", the Guardians, journalist who have been targeted for their work. There are four covers, one features Jamal Khashoggi, the murdered Washington Post columnist, another highlights Maria Ressa, a Philippine journalist. The third features two Reuters journalists who were arrested a year ago for their reporting on Muslims, and the final cover shows the staff of the Capital Gazette. Their office, you know, was the target of a shooting earlier this year. That is the Time Magazine Person of the Year. Reaction?

MCDOWELL: Meaningful and it expresses American values. And the value of the first amendment, and how journalist to break news, put their lives on the line very often. So, I give -- I give kudos to Time for this very much.

BARTIROMO: Yes, this was a great idea to do this, and they should be heralded and cherished for their important work.

Meanwhile, what a night last night. I know I've been telling you all about what I did last night. I went to see Italian songwriter and tenor Andrea Bocelli perform in New York City. It was a private concert at the Columbus Citizens Foundation. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It was such a memorable night. I love Andrea Bocelli. I took my sister and next to me is the wife of Andrea Bocelli, Veronica. The -- and there's Lidia Bastianich, as well, along with myself and my sister. We talked about the Andrea Bocelli Foundation which raises money for underprivileged people. As the Columbus Foundation brought together the Andrea Bocelli Foundation. Thank you to both. It was fun.

MCDOWELL: Jealous.

(LAUGHTER)

END

urn:contentItem:5WMY-CG41-JBHT-D414-00000-00New Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In Art2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisNew Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In ArtLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, we are. Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much. We will see you in a little bit. Big day today. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, December 11th. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the EAST COAST. Stocks are extending gains right now, we are at the highs of the morning with a big rally underway. Dow Industrials set to open up this morning better than a hundred points, the S&P 500 is up 10, and the NASDAQ up 38 points, that's two-thirds of one percent higher this morning.

After a wild day yesterday on Wall Street, markets were volatile, climbing from the lowest to the end of the day in positive territory. Big rally toward the end of the day, taking the market off of the lows. The Dow had been down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May delayed the vote on the deal to leave the European Union. Then, by the close, as you can see, markets reversed course. Up 34 points at the close on the Dow.

Global markets this morning are also seeing a bit of a bounce, take a look at FT-100 up better than one percent, 69 points higher, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 71 points, one and a half percent higher, and the DAX Index in Germany also higher by one and a half percent, that's a hundred and fifty- seven points higher this morning. In Asia overnight, markets with little change, as you can see there, very fractional moves and mixed. Trade talks are moving forward. The U.S. and China holding a new round of negotiations last night. We have the very latest on where that stands.

And coming together, President Trump set to meet with House Minority Leader, Nancy Pelosi, and funding the border wall among top items on the agenda, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi will go to the White House. Democrats reportedly ready to offer to $1.3 billion for the wall, but that is the short of the President's $5 billion request. Google's turn on the hot seat today. CEO Sundar Pichai's headed to Capitol Hill today. He will testify before the House Judiciary Committee. FOX Business will bring you that live at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will take a look at what to expect from his testimony this morning.

Then Nirvana's Smells Like Teen Spirit losing its crown as the most streamed song from the 20th century. We'll tell you what tune knocked it off the top spot, all that coming up this morning. All those stories coming up. Joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, and Beyond Sport Global Ambassador, Fox News Contributor, John Layfield. It's great to see you this morning.

JOHN LAYFIELD FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR AND BEYOND SPORT GLOBAL AMBASSADOR: It's great to see you. Going to be a crazy week. With the Brexit, its potential government shutdown, this is going to be nuts.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Nice to see the green though in the market this morning, really. Positive reaction to some of this trade news and especially in Europe, all in the green after yesterday's Brexit.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see how it closes. The market's volatility has been just unreal.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. It's a market that's trading off headlines, that's trading off commentary, from somebody, anybody, everybody, coming out of the White House, and I think that that's going to be the case. Other than the Federal Reserve meeting in the month of December, that's really the only, like, hardcore piece of news that we have coming up that we -- that we know about.

BARTIROMO: We talked yesterday about the fact that the President of France, Macron, has not been seen in the face of all of these riots. We did hear from him yesterday, Dagen. What did do you think?

MCDOWELL: He is pledging tax cuts and minimum wage hikes to placate protesters, but, again, I want to point out that the -- kind of the kickoff to these yellow-vest protests was a gas tax hike to push his environmental agenda, and I think that that is an actually -- it's an honest move because that is what it does take if you want to broadly reduce emissions and push an environmentalist agenda. It's -- everybody bears the cost of it. That gas tax hike has completely gone away, but the protestors have still been out four weekends in a row so I -- I'm curious to see if this really does kind of soothe the unrest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because they say --

MCDOWELL: -- and the --

BARTIROMO: -- he's out of touch, which is the -- which is the criticism.

MCDOWELL: All right. But I need to give Nile Gardiner credit.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: I used the phrase "swanning about the globe while (INAUDIBLE) capital city is burning. Nile used that phrase over the weekend. So, credit to Nile on that.

BARTIROMO: And he was great when he joined us to --

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: -- navigate all of this. We got a big show this morning. Coming up, joining the conversation this morning, Ohio Congressman and House Judiciary Committee Member, Jim Jordan is here. We're going to talk with the Congressman about that Google hearing among other things. Plus Jim Comey, lots to talk about with Jim Jordan. Michigan Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member, Debbie Dingell, is with us this morning. Congresswoman Dingell has a lot to say about General Motors. Plus the Chairman and CEO of Motorola Solutions, Greg Brown, is with us this morning. He's turned that company around.

And Former British Parliament Member Euro Pacific Capital Senior Economic Consultant, John Browne, is here as well. Plus FOX News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane joins us as well. Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big three hours coming up. We kick it off right here with this top story, and that is all of these swings in the market. Checking Futures right now, we're expecting a pretty strong opening for today's trading. Dow Industrials right now up a hundred and twelve points, a half a percent higher after a wild day yesterday when the Dow slid to session lows down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May announced a delay of the exit vote, Britain leaving European Union.

But look at that chart, markets reverse in course, as the session wore on and as you can see, after the lows hit at about 11:15 a.m. in the morning, things slowly but surely came back only to end higher. When we were down at 11:15 market better than 500 points. Market was briefly in correction territory down 20 percent from the high, that means. Joining us right now, CIO, EventShares CIO Ben Phillips. And Ben, it is good to have you on the program this morning.

BEN PHILLIPS, CIO, EVENTSHARES: Thanks for having me, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What a market. How are you doing with all this volatility?

PHILLIPS: Well, we've done some things in portfolio raise cash actually on the Fed pop. I guess that was a couple of Wednesdays ago. So, we had a big day up, markets were up about two percent. We actually raised cash to 17 percent in portfolio.

BARTIROMO: Oh, wow. Big number.

PHILLIPS: Yes. So, it was a meaningful move. You know, I think the thought was get a little more defensive. We were pretty skeptical on anything positive coming out of G20. And so after we actually saw that over the weekend, we started to look -- even get a little more defensive.

BARTIROMO: But longer term, has anything changed in terms of structural, you know, performance for this market? Look At the backdrop --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in terms of growth expectations, higher rates, has anything specifically changed that you really want to shift your allocation and hold it in cash and just like --

PHILLIPS: Well, I think we have to realize that we are late cycle, and there's going to be more late-cycle activity. The Fed is pumping the brakes and what that means is the rate-sensitive sectors are going to see some of that, you know, giveback and that's what we're seeing. I think it's normal to see this type of activity towards the end of the cycle as the Feds starts its heightening cycle. So, you know, they said don't fight the Fed for the past 10 years effectively, don't fight the Feds still, you know. They're tightening for a reason, that's going to have implications on markets.

BELL: One trend that we've seen though on these days, these mornings when you're up like this by a nice amount --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BELL: -- we've seen that pop, initial pop, sold into the end of the day and we end the day --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

BELL: -- at the lows, do you expect that today? When can that trend turn around?

PHILLIPS: Yes, you know, I hear the question. It's tough to call it a day-to-day move obviously.

BELL: Yes.

PHILLIPS: But I -- you know, I talked to people about a potential rally, you know, a Santa rally, or even a January rally, which is somewhat typical. People are looking to fade, looking to sell into it. So, I think that's going to be a trend we're going to see here. There's been a rotation that's occurred at the hedge funds where they've derisked. They've brought down leverage and now we're at a situation where they still have a little bit more to go, I think. They're still long tech, they're still long momentum, so they still have some unwinding of that trade to do. So, if they're actually thinking the cycle's over, or it's close to the end, the -- that rotation's going to continue.

LAYFIELD: Yesterday, we had all talks about Brexit, the week before, it was all about G20.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

LAYFIELD: If you take out the geopolitical events and you trade only on the market, what would the market be doing right now?

PHILLIPS: Well, that's tough. It's tough. I mean all we do is connect the geopolitical events --

LAYFIELD: Right.

PHILLIPS: -- to the market. So, to say what would happen if there weren't is -- I mean I think the market would be stronger. I think, you know, trade --

LAYFIELD: I guess my question is --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- are we headed for a recession, are we headed for a slowdown? Would this market still be selling off even into a Christmas rally? Which looks to be a great Christmas retail season --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- but people wonder, is this is the last hurrah? What's your view?

PHILLIPS: I think if we remove the geopolitical, we could see a rally here. We -- I think we should see a rally here. Growth --

BARTIROMO: So you're not expecting a growth slowdown?

PHILLIPS: No. What I think is causing it is the confidence crisis right now. We've seen China trade actually slowing some supply chains, causing some drag on growth across the world. So, that's happening. Now, if there is a true pause and we start seeing constructive discussions between U.S. And China, we could see that actually, you know, reverse course in the market.

BARTIROMO: In fact, we have a new round of trade talks that we are reporting this morning. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, holding a call last night with their Chinese counterparts, reportedly discussing agricultural purchases, changes to China's fundamental economic policies, according to the Wall Street Journal, and this comes amid heightened tensions over the arrest of Huawei CFO. She's still waiting to find out whether she will be released on bail. The decision could come today. So, this is all intertwined.

We did hear -- as soon as he came back from Argentina, Dagen, that the President said China was going to buy all these agricultural products, remember? $1.3 trillion --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- was the number.

MCDOWELL: Because of the trade fight that we've gotten into with China. And it's a two-party fight, it's not a one-party fight, and it's really hurt farmers. Farmers have gotten multibillion dollar bailout from the Federal government to help them out. That will be good news. But I would caution that there needs to be one voice, while they -- while the U.S. goes through these trade talks, there needs to be one voice on this, and I would say it would be the President of the United States.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: I think investors have become accustomed to the way the President communicates. People can call it what they want, but that's who he is --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- as Donald Trump, President of the United States. I think that this is a moment where a lot of these talking heads in the WHITE HOUSE need to stay off television. And I said that yesterday about Peter Navarro.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But, again, there needs to be one voice and clearly there's been fighting within the White House over time between Lighthizer, and Navarro, and Mnuchin, and maybe even Larry Kudlow. So, just let the President talk about it. That's it.

BARTIROMO: Apparently, they did have this call last night.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Did that change opinions in your view on Wall Street in terms of where we are in this negotiation?

PHILLIPS: You know, I think it's positive to see that we're back at the table. Since July --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PHILLIPS: -- really, the Chinese and the U.S. Governments weren't really at the table at a senior level. It was -- it was barely even junior staffers having conversations. So, it's positive to see that. I think we saw Trump and Xi go back home after the G20. While there wasn't a joint communication, they did go back home and they both tried to spend it domestically. "Hey, we got some things done. There is some progress." We took that as a positive cue. (END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: "Bohemian Rhapsody," the most streamed song from the 20th Century. It is also seen as spiking popularity, obviously, since the release of the Freddie Mercury biopic movie that came out last month, which was huge hit, by the way at the box officer. Here is the rest of top five: at number five, "Take on Me" by A-ha -- remember that one? Right? I love that we're all 80s kids here. Guns 'n Roses, has the next two spots with "November Rain" and "Sweet Child of Mine." Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit" has been played more than 1.5 billion. And yes, "Bohemian Rhapsody," despite being six minutes long, number one, 1.6 billion streams. I love that we all get each other in our musical taste.

BARTIROMO: I love all of those songs.

CASONE: Me too.

BARTIROMO: I think I'm going to have "Take on Me" in my head all day, though, now.

MCDOWELL: A-ha, of all bands, to make the top five. And "November Rain," really, kind of one of the bottom, like, five songs ever recorded by G&R. What about "Welcome to the Jungle," or (INAUDIBLE), any of that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, where was that?

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly.

BARTIROMO: All right. Well, take a break, when we come back, the finer things; why more people are investing in their money in fine arts? That's straight ahead. Wait until you see what we've got to show you next up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, as we look at the stock market rallying this morning, we're also looking at art as an investment as the number of billionaires and wealthy individuals continues to grow. More and more are turn to fine art as a way to invest their money according to the 2017 Night Frank Luxury Investment Index, art was the most popular luxury investment ahead of assets like wine, coins and jewelry. Joining us right now is Fine Art Curator, Michael Witmer. Michael, it's good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

MICHAEL WITMER, FINE ART CURATOR: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So, tell us what's been happening over the last, what, couple of years in number of the number of billionaires investing their money in art?

WITMER: We're seeing more billionaires being created than ever before. We're seeing them being created in far fun places where we haven't seen billionaires before throughout Asia: China, India, and places like Malaysia, the Philippines which didn't have many billionaires. They're building their own museums, they're pushing up the prices. We will continue to see blue chip prices go through the roof because that's what they want for the walls of their museums. So, we're seeing the supply go down and demand go up.

BARTIROMO: What kind of art are they most interested in?

WITMER: They seems to be interested in real museum pieces for -- especially French impressionism, early modern artist like Picasso, Mone, van Gogh. We will probably see prices of the good old (INAUDIBLE) start to go up again. And once we see those go up, there's no stopping them.

PHILLIPS: Is it (INAUDIBLE) independent. (INAUDIBLE) American billionaires buys different artist, a Da Vinci art or a Picasso for instance, compared to, say, Asian billionaires?

WITMER: It used to be that way. But now, we've seen a worldwide increase, drastic increase in museum attendance, more people are studying art history than ever before. If you look 26 years ago with the Louvre, there were 2.5 million visitors and they thought they would never get that high. Last year and the year before, it was just barely shy of 10 million visitors.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

WITMER: Most major museums are seeing that. So, as a result, to answer your question, we're seeing the museums throughout the world, the billionaire collectors throughout the world now collecting the same thing.

BARTIROMO: I love this story. I want to ask you about this mystery, though, in the art world. Last year, we saw the most expensive art sale on record. We talked about it on this program a lot, you came on the show to discuss it. This was Leonardo da Vinci's Salvatore Mundi. It was bought by Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for $450 million. Now, the master piece has not been seen since its purchase last year. Scholars are worried about where it is, where is this painting, where do you think?

WITMER: At $450 million, that painting had its own armed guards and escorts everywhere it went. It was probably as safe as President Trump has ever been. It's not uncommon in the part of the world for the buyers to hang something in the living room, enjoy it for a little while, and then share it with the world. Also, because they're building beautiful new Louvre museum that is now opened, it's spectacular.

BARTIROMO: In Saudi.

WITMER: Yes, and they're building more -- that's in Abu Dhabi, and they're building more museums throughout that region. So, they may be looking to make more acquisitions before they show everything. The idea that one 450 million-dollar Leonardo is not enough.

BARTIROMO: Amazing story. Yes, maybe it is in MBS's home?

WITMER: Could be.

BARTIROMO: Michael, good to see you.

WITMER: Good to see you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. We will be right back. Google is in the hot seat. We're going to talk about a CEO Sundar Pichai headed to Capitol Hill to testify, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END
