Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TY1-XH71-DXH2-600S-00000-00New Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In Art2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTBen Phillips, Daniel Ives, Michael WitmerNEWSFinancial121101cb.231New Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In ArtMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lindsey Bell, Cheryl Casone, John Layfield, Jack Keane

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, we are. Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much. We will see you in a little bit. Big day today. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, December 11th. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the EAST COAST. Stocks are extending gains right now, we are at the highs of the morning with a big rally underway. Dow Industrials set to open up this morning better than a hundred points, the S&P 500 is up 10, and the NASDAQ up 38 points, that's two-thirds of one percent higher this morning.

After a wild day yesterday on Wall Street, markets were volatile, climbing from the lowest to the end of the day in positive territory. Big rally toward the end of the day, taking the market off of the lows. The Dow had been down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May delayed the vote on the deal to leave the European Union. Then, by the close, as you can see, markets reversed course. Up 34 points at the close on the Dow.

Global markets this morning are also seeing a bit of a bounce, take a look at FT-100 up better than one percent, 69 points higher, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 71 points, one and a half percent higher, and the DAX Index in Germany also higher by one and a half percent, that's a hundred and fifty- seven points higher this morning. In Asia overnight, markets with little change, as you can see there, very fractional moves and mixed. Trade talks are moving forward. The U.S. and China holding a new round of negotiations last night. We have the very latest on where that stands.

And coming together, President Trump set to meet with House Minority Leader, Nancy Pelosi, and funding the border wall among top items on the agenda, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi will go to the White House. Democrats reportedly ready to offer to $1.3 billion for the wall, but that is the short of the President's $5 billion request. Google's turn on the hot seat today. CEO Sundar Pichai's headed to Capitol Hill today. He will testify before the House Judiciary Committee. FOX Business will bring you that live at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will take a look at what to expect from his testimony this morning.

Then Nirvana's Smells Like Teen Spirit losing its crown as the most streamed song from the 20th century. We'll tell you what tune knocked it off the top spot, all that coming up this morning. All those stories coming up. Joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, and Beyond Sport Global Ambassador, Fox News Contributor, John Layfield. It's great to see you this morning.

JOHN LAYFIELD FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR AND BEYOND SPORT GLOBAL AMBASSADOR: It's great to see you. Going to be a crazy week. With the Brexit, its potential government shutdown, this is going to be nuts.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Nice to see the green though in the market this morning, really. Positive reaction to some of this trade news and especially in Europe, all in the green after yesterday's Brexit.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see how it closes. The market's volatility has been just unreal.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. It's a market that's trading off headlines, that's trading off commentary, from somebody, anybody, everybody, coming out of the White House, and I think that that's going to be the case. Other than the Federal Reserve meeting in the month of December, that's really the only, like, hardcore piece of news that we have coming up that we -- that we know about.

BARTIROMO: We talked yesterday about the fact that the President of France, Macron, has not been seen in the face of all of these riots. We did hear from him yesterday, Dagen. What did do you think?

MCDOWELL: He is pledging tax cuts and minimum wage hikes to placate protesters, but, again, I want to point out that the -- kind of the kickoff to these yellow-vest protests was a gas tax hike to push his environmental agenda, and I think that that is an actually -- it's an honest move because that is what it does take if you want to broadly reduce emissions and push an environmentalist agenda. It's -- everybody bears the cost of it. That gas tax hike has completely gone away, but the protestors have still been out four weekends in a row so I -- I'm curious to see if this really does kind of soothe the unrest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because they say --

MCDOWELL: -- and the --

BARTIROMO: -- he's out of touch, which is the -- which is the criticism.

MCDOWELL: All right. But I need to give Nile Gardiner credit.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: I used the phrase "swanning about the globe while (INAUDIBLE) capital city is burning. Nile used that phrase over the weekend. So, credit to Nile on that.

BARTIROMO: And he was great when he joined us to --

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: -- navigate all of this. We got a big show this morning. Coming up, joining the conversation this morning, Ohio Congressman and House Judiciary Committee Member, Jim Jordan is here. We're going to talk with the Congressman about that Google hearing among other things. Plus Jim Comey, lots to talk about with Jim Jordan. Michigan Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member, Debbie Dingell, is with us this morning. Congresswoman Dingell has a lot to say about General Motors. Plus the Chairman and CEO of Motorola Solutions, Greg Brown, is with us this morning. He's turned that company around.

And Former British Parliament Member Euro Pacific Capital Senior Economic Consultant, John Browne, is here as well. Plus FOX News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane joins us as well. Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big three hours coming up. We kick it off right here with this top story, and that is all of these swings in the market. Checking Futures right now, we're expecting a pretty strong opening for today's trading. Dow Industrials right now up a hundred and twelve points, a half a percent higher after a wild day yesterday when the Dow slid to session lows down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May announced a delay of the exit vote, Britain leaving European Union.

But look at that chart, markets reverse in course, as the session wore on and as you can see, after the lows hit at about 11:15 a.m. in the morning, things slowly but surely came back only to end higher. When we were down at 11:15 market better than 500 points. Market was briefly in correction territory down 20 percent from the high, that means. Joining us right now, CIO, EventShares CIO Ben Phillips. And Ben, it is good to have you on the program this morning.

BEN PHILLIPS, CIO, EVENTSHARES: Thanks for having me, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What a market. How are you doing with all this volatility?

PHILLIPS: Well, we've done some things in portfolio raise cash actually on the Fed pop. I guess that was a couple of Wednesdays ago. So, we had a big day up, markets were up about two percent. We actually raised cash to 17 percent in portfolio.

BARTIROMO: Oh, wow. Big number.

PHILLIPS: Yes. So, it was a meaningful move. You know, I think the thought was get a little more defensive. We were pretty skeptical on anything positive coming out of G20. And so after we actually saw that over the weekend, we started to look -- even get a little more defensive.

BARTIROMO: But longer term, has anything changed in terms of structural, you know, performance for this market? Look At the backdrop --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in terms of growth expectations, higher rates, has anything specifically changed that you really want to shift your allocation and hold it in cash and just like --

PHILLIPS: Well, I think we have to realize that we are late cycle, and there's going to be more late-cycle activity. The Fed is pumping the brakes and what that means is the rate-sensitive sectors are going to see some of that, you know, giveback and that's what we're seeing. I think it's normal to see this type of activity towards the end of the cycle as the Feds starts its heightening cycle. So, you know, they said don't fight the Fed for the past 10 years effectively, don't fight the Feds still, you know. They're tightening for a reason, that's going to have implications on markets.

BELL: One trend that we've seen though on these days, these mornings when you're up like this by a nice amount --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BELL: -- we've seen that pop, initial pop, sold into the end of the day and we end the day --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

BELL: -- at the lows, do you expect that today? When can that trend turn around?

PHILLIPS: Yes, you know, I hear the question. It's tough to call it a day-to-day move obviously.

BELL: Yes.

PHILLIPS: But I -- you know, I talked to people about a potential rally, you know, a Santa rally, or even a January rally, which is somewhat typical. People are looking to fade, looking to sell into it. So, I think that's going to be a trend we're going to see here. There's been a rotation that's occurred at the hedge funds where they've derisked. They've brought down leverage and now we're at a situation where they still have a little bit more to go, I think. They're still long tech, they're still long momentum, so they still have some unwinding of that trade to do. So, if they're actually thinking the cycle's over, or it's close to the end, the -- that rotation's going to continue.

LAYFIELD: Yesterday, we had all talks about Brexit, the week before, it was all about G20.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

LAYFIELD: If you take out the geopolitical events and you trade only on the market, what would the market be doing right now?

PHILLIPS: Well, that's tough. It's tough. I mean all we do is connect the geopolitical events --

LAYFIELD: Right.

PHILLIPS: -- to the market. So, to say what would happen if there weren't is -- I mean I think the market would be stronger. I think, you know, trade --

LAYFIELD: I guess my question is --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- are we headed for a recession, are we headed for a slowdown? Would this market still be selling off even into a Christmas rally? Which looks to be a great Christmas retail season --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- but people wonder, is this is the last hurrah? What's your view?

PHILLIPS: I think if we remove the geopolitical, we could see a rally here. We -- I think we should see a rally here. Growth --

BARTIROMO: So you're not expecting a growth slowdown?

PHILLIPS: No. What I think is causing it is the confidence crisis right now. We've seen China trade actually slowing some supply chains, causing some drag on growth across the world. So, that's happening. Now, if there is a true pause and we start seeing constructive discussions between U.S. And China, we could see that actually, you know, reverse course in the market.

BARTIROMO: In fact, we have a new round of trade talks that we are reporting this morning. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, holding a call last night with their Chinese counterparts, reportedly discussing agricultural purchases, changes to China's fundamental economic policies, according to the Wall Street Journal, and this comes amid heightened tensions over the arrest of Huawei CFO. She's still waiting to find out whether she will be released on bail. The decision could come today. So, this is all intertwined.

We did hear -- as soon as he came back from Argentina, Dagen, that the President said China was going to buy all these agricultural products, remember? $1.3 trillion --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- was the number.

MCDOWELL: Because of the trade fight that we've gotten into with China. And it's a two-party fight, it's not a one-party fight, and it's really hurt farmers. Farmers have gotten multibillion dollar bailout from the Federal government to help them out. That will be good news. But I would caution that there needs to be one voice, while they -- while the U.S. goes through these trade talks, there needs to be one voice on this, and I would say it would be the President of the United States.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: I think investors have become accustomed to the way the President communicates. People can call it what they want, but that's who he is --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- as Donald Trump, President of the United States. I think that this is a moment where a lot of these talking heads in the WHITE HOUSE need to stay off television. And I said that yesterday about Peter Navarro.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But, again, there needs to be one voice and clearly there's been fighting within the White House over time between Lighthizer, and Navarro, and Mnuchin, and maybe even Larry Kudlow. So, just let the President talk about it. That's it.

BARTIROMO: Apparently, they did have this call last night.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Did that change opinions in your view on Wall Street in terms of where we are in this negotiation?

PHILLIPS: You know, I think it's positive to see that we're back at the table. Since July --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PHILLIPS: -- really, the Chinese and the U.S. Governments weren't really at the table at a senior level. It was -- it was barely even junior staffers having conversations. So, it's positive to see that. I think we saw Trump and Xi go back home after the G20. While there wasn't a joint communication, they did go back home and they both tried to spend it domestically. "Hey, we got some things done. There is some progress." We took that as a positive cue. If you look at one silver lining from the G20, I think that's it, that they said "We have to get something done here." They're looking at the markets, both of them. Their respective domestic markets.

BARTIROMO: But you do think we're seeing this rally today because of this new talk last night, right?

BELL: Yes, I definitely think that the rally we're seeing --

BARTIROMO: That's what's pushing --

BELL: -- this morning is because of that.

BARTIROMO: Right now.

BELL: Yes.

BELL: We also have another push for tax reform, Ben. So what about that? I mean House Ways and Means Committee Chairman --

PHILLIPS: I don't think that's what's driving markets today.

BARTIROMO: OK. Because Kevin Brady is retooling this tax cuts 2.0 right now.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: He's trying to secure more Republican votes, the bill delayed several healthcare taxes that allows expecting parents to create 529 plans for their unborn children.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: So, you don't think that has an impact in any way, right?

PHILLIPS: No, I think that the plan he released, I think it was the Wednesday after Thanksgiving or the week after Thanksgiving was more bipartisan-looking and I think that the revisions are more partisan. And so it seems pretty lame ducky some politicking at this point in time.

MCDOWELL: And speaking of politics, I'll throw this in. I'm hearing this more and more from investors. They're really waiting for the Mueller report to come out, and they point to the two months before the Ken Starr report came out in 1998, which was in September of that year, granted that was the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management at that time as well, so it's hard to separate the two, but in the two months, between mid-July and the Starr report coming out in September, the S&P fell almost 20 percent.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: About -- more than 90 percent. Granted the market made back all that loss by the end of November, but this is -- people are standing back and now waiting as more and more filings come out of the Mueller Team, out of the U.S. Attorney in the -- for the Southern District of NEW YORK on Friday, that's becoming a focus as well. And I -- Gary B. talked about it over the weekend.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it's one of three really important things that will probably give us a sense of what's going to happen in 2020.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Number one, who did the Democrats put out there to go against President Trump? Number two, how's the economy doing? We'll see if we are in a growth slowdown come 2020, and number three, the Mueller report.

MCDOWELL: I want to --

BARTIROMO: What comes out of Mueller?

MCDOWELL: I want to add one more thing. I think the markets -- and I know you'll agree with me, are -- you're getting a little bit of a lift moving into the week because we did get an inversion of the yield curve between the two-year and the 10-year to where, you know, if the shorter rates are higher, that indicates the recession it has for the last 50 years, we didn't get that last week, and I think that there was a bit of relief among investors (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Because as it was coming close, the two-year --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- and the 10-year markets were selling off.

MCDOWELL: Right. As narrow as it was since 2007, but we didn't get that inversion and --

BELL: And the reporting on the Fed potentially walking back, maybe taking --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BELL: -- more of a dovish tone obviously played well into that.

BARTIROMO: Right. Do you buy into that? Fed's not going to raise as many as people think right now?

PHILLIPS: I -- yes.

It was bought by Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for $450 million. Now, the master piece has not been seen since its purchase last year. Scholars are worried about where it is, where is this painting, where do you think?

WITMER: At $450 million, that painting had its own armed guards and escorts everywhere it went. It was probably as safe as President Trump has ever been. It's not uncommon in the part of the world for the buyers to hang something in the living room, enjoy it for a little while, and then share it with the world. Also, because they're building beautiful new Louvre museum that is now opened, it's spectacular.

BARTIROMO: In Saudi.

WITMER: Yes, and they're building more -- that's in Abu Dhabi, and they're building more museums throughout that region. So, they may be looking to make more acquisitions before they show everything. The idea that one 450 million-dollar Leonardo is not enough.

BARTIROMO: Amazing story. Yes, maybe it is in MBS's home?

WITMER: Could be.

BARTIROMO: Michael, good to see you.

WITMER: Good to see you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. We will be right back. Google is in the hot seat. We're going to talk about a CEO Sundar Pichai headed to Capitol Hill to testify, stay with us.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TYD-9001-DY0W-41FD-00000-00New Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In Art2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisNew Trade Talks; Gollum Takes on Brexit; Macron Makes Promises to Protesters; British Prime Minister Spokesman Says New U.K. Exit Vote Could Happen By January 21; Trump To Meet With Pelosi, Schumer Over Border Amid Looming Shutdown; Defense Spending Hike; Five Marines Declared Dead; 20th Century's Top Streams; Investing In ArtLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, we are. Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much. We will see you in a little bit. Big day today. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, December 11th. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the EAST COAST. Stocks are extending gains right now, we are at the highs of the morning with a big rally underway. Dow Industrials set to open up this morning better than a hundred points, the S&P 500 is up 10, and the NASDAQ up 38 points, that's two-thirds of one percent higher this morning.

After a wild day yesterday on Wall Street, markets were volatile, climbing from the lowest to the end of the day in positive territory. Big rally toward the end of the day, taking the market off of the lows. The Dow had been down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May delayed the vote on the deal to leave the European Union. Then, by the close, as you can see, markets reversed course. Up 34 points at the close on the Dow.

Global markets this morning are also seeing a bit of a bounce, take a look at FT-100 up better than one percent, 69 points higher, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 71 points, one and a half percent higher, and the DAX Index in Germany also higher by one and a half percent, that's a hundred and fifty- seven points higher this morning. In Asia overnight, markets with little change, as you can see there, very fractional moves and mixed. Trade talks are moving forward. The U.S. and China holding a new round of negotiations last night. We have the very latest on where that stands.

And coming together, President Trump set to meet with House Minority Leader, Nancy Pelosi, and funding the border wall among top items on the agenda, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi will go to the White House. Democrats reportedly ready to offer to $1.3 billion for the wall, but that is the short of the President's $5 billion request. Google's turn on the hot seat today. CEO Sundar Pichai's headed to Capitol Hill today. He will testify before the House Judiciary Committee. FOX Business will bring you that live at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will take a look at what to expect from his testimony this morning.

Then Nirvana's Smells Like Teen Spirit losing its crown as the most streamed song from the 20th century. We'll tell you what tune knocked it off the top spot, all that coming up this morning. All those stories coming up. Joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, and Beyond Sport Global Ambassador, Fox News Contributor, John Layfield. It's great to see you this morning.

JOHN LAYFIELD FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR AND BEYOND SPORT GLOBAL AMBASSADOR: It's great to see you. Going to be a crazy week. With the Brexit, its potential government shutdown, this is going to be nuts.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Nice to see the green though in the market this morning, really. Positive reaction to some of this trade news and especially in Europe, all in the green after yesterday's Brexit.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see how it closes. The market's volatility has been just unreal.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. It's a market that's trading off headlines, that's trading off commentary, from somebody, anybody, everybody, coming out of the White House, and I think that that's going to be the case. Other than the Federal Reserve meeting in the month of December, that's really the only, like, hardcore piece of news that we have coming up that we -- that we know about.

BARTIROMO: We talked yesterday about the fact that the President of France, Macron, has not been seen in the face of all of these riots. We did hear from him yesterday, Dagen. What did do you think?

MCDOWELL: He is pledging tax cuts and minimum wage hikes to placate protesters, but, again, I want to point out that the -- kind of the kickoff to these yellow-vest protests was a gas tax hike to push his environmental agenda, and I think that that is an actually -- it's an honest move because that is what it does take if you want to broadly reduce emissions and push an environmentalist agenda. It's -- everybody bears the cost of it. That gas tax hike has completely gone away, but the protestors have still been out four weekends in a row so I -- I'm curious to see if this really does kind of soothe the unrest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because they say --

MCDOWELL: -- and the --

BARTIROMO: -- he's out of touch, which is the -- which is the criticism.

MCDOWELL: All right. But I need to give Nile Gardiner credit.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: I used the phrase "swanning about the globe while (INAUDIBLE) capital city is burning. Nile used that phrase over the weekend. So, credit to Nile on that.

BARTIROMO: And he was great when he joined us to --

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: -- navigate all of this. We got a big show this morning. Coming up, joining the conversation this morning, Ohio Congressman and House Judiciary Committee Member, Jim Jordan is here. We're going to talk with the Congressman about that Google hearing among other things. Plus Jim Comey, lots to talk about with Jim Jordan. Michigan Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member, Debbie Dingell, is with us this morning. Congresswoman Dingell has a lot to say about General Motors. Plus the Chairman and CEO of Motorola Solutions, Greg Brown, is with us this morning. He's turned that company around.

And Former British Parliament Member Euro Pacific Capital Senior Economic Consultant, John Browne, is here as well. Plus FOX News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane joins us as well. Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big three hours coming up. We kick it off right here with this top story, and that is all of these swings in the market. Checking Futures right now, we're expecting a pretty strong opening for today's trading. Dow Industrials right now up a hundred and twelve points, a half a percent higher after a wild day yesterday when the Dow slid to session lows down better than 500 points after British Prime Minister Theresa May announced a delay of the exit vote, Britain leaving European Union.

But look at that chart, markets reverse in course, as the session wore on and as you can see, after the lows hit at about 11:15 a.m. in the morning, things slowly but surely came back only to end higher. When we were down at 11:15 market better than 500 points. Market was briefly in correction territory down 20 percent from the high, that means. Joining us right now, CIO, EventShares CIO Ben Phillips. And Ben, it is good to have you on the program this morning.

BEN PHILLIPS, CIO, EVENTSHARES: Thanks for having me, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What a market. How are you doing with all this volatility?

PHILLIPS: Well, we've done some things in portfolio raise cash actually on the Fed pop. I guess that was a couple of Wednesdays ago. So, we had a big day up, markets were up about two percent. We actually raised cash to 17 percent in portfolio.

BARTIROMO: Oh, wow. Big number.

PHILLIPS: Yes. So, it was a meaningful move. You know, I think the thought was get a little more defensive. We were pretty skeptical on anything positive coming out of G20. And so after we actually saw that over the weekend, we started to look -- even get a little more defensive.

BARTIROMO: But longer term, has anything changed in terms of structural, you know, performance for this market? Look At the backdrop --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in terms of growth expectations, higher rates, has anything specifically changed that you really want to shift your allocation and hold it in cash and just like --

PHILLIPS: Well, I think we have to realize that we are late cycle, and there's going to be more late-cycle activity. The Fed is pumping the brakes and what that means is the rate-sensitive sectors are going to see some of that, you know, giveback and that's what we're seeing. I think it's normal to see this type of activity towards the end of the cycle as the Feds starts its heightening cycle. So, you know, they said don't fight the Fed for the past 10 years effectively, don't fight the Feds still, you know. They're tightening for a reason, that's going to have implications on markets.

BELL: One trend that we've seen though on these days, these mornings when you're up like this by a nice amount --

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BELL: -- we've seen that pop, initial pop, sold into the end of the day and we end the day --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

BELL: -- at the lows, do you expect that today? When can that trend turn around?

PHILLIPS: Yes, you know, I hear the question. It's tough to call it a day-to-day move obviously.

BELL: Yes.

PHILLIPS: But I -- you know, I talked to people about a potential rally, you know, a Santa rally, or even a January rally, which is somewhat typical. People are looking to fade, looking to sell into it. So, I think that's going to be a trend we're going to see here. There's been a rotation that's occurred at the hedge funds where they've derisked. They've brought down leverage and now we're at a situation where they still have a little bit more to go, I think. They're still long tech, they're still long momentum, so they still have some unwinding of that trade to do. So, if they're actually thinking the cycle's over, or it's close to the end, the -- that rotation's going to continue.

LAYFIELD: Yesterday, we had all talks about Brexit, the week before, it was all about G20.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

LAYFIELD: If you take out the geopolitical events and you trade only on the market, what would the market be doing right now?

PHILLIPS: Well, that's tough. It's tough. I mean all we do is connect the geopolitical events --

LAYFIELD: Right.

PHILLIPS: -- to the market. So, to say what would happen if there weren't is -- I mean I think the market would be stronger. I think, you know, trade --

LAYFIELD: I guess my question is --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- are we headed for a recession, are we headed for a slowdown? Would this market still be selling off even into a Christmas rally? Which looks to be a great Christmas retail season --

PHILLIPS: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- but people wonder, is this is the last hurrah? What's your view?

PHILLIPS: I think if we remove the geopolitical, we could see a rally here. We -- I think we should see a rally here. Growth --

BARTIROMO: So you're not expecting a growth slowdown?

PHILLIPS: No. What I think is causing it is the confidence crisis right now. We've seen China trade actually slowing some supply chains, causing some drag on growth across the world. So, that's happening. Now, if there is a true pause and we start seeing constructive discussions between U.S. And China, we could see that actually, you know, reverse course in the market.

BARTIROMO: In fact, we have a new round of trade talks that we are reporting this morning. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, holding a call last night with their Chinese counterparts, reportedly discussing agricultural purchases, changes to China's fundamental economic policies, according to the Wall Street Journal, and this comes amid heightened tensions over the arrest of Huawei CFO. She's still waiting to find out whether she will be released on bail. The decision could come today. So, this is all intertwined.

We did hear -- as soon as he came back from Argentina, Dagen, that the President said China was going to buy all these agricultural products, remember? $1.3 trillion --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- was the number.

MCDOWELL: Because of the trade fight that we've gotten into with China. And it's a two-party fight, it's not a one-party fight, and it's really hurt farmers. Farmers have gotten multibillion dollar bailout from the Federal government to help them out. That will be good news. But I would caution that there needs to be one voice, while they -- while the U.S. goes through these trade talks, there needs to be one voice on this, and I would say it would be the President of the United States.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: I think investors have become accustomed to the way the President communicates. People can call it what they want, but that's who he is --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- as Donald Trump, President of the United States. I think that this is a moment where a lot of these talking heads in the WHITE HOUSE need to stay off television. And I said that yesterday about Peter Navarro.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But, again, there needs to be one voice and clearly there's been fighting within the White House over time between Lighthizer, and Navarro, and Mnuchin, and maybe even Larry Kudlow. So, just let the President talk about it. That's it.

BARTIROMO: Apparently, they did have this call last night.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Did that change opinions in your view on Wall Street in terms of where we are in this negotiation?

PHILLIPS: You know, I think it's positive to see that we're back at the table. Since July --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PHILLIPS: -- really, the Chinese and the U.S. Governments weren't really at the table at a senior level. It was -- it was barely even junior staffers having conversations. So, it's positive to see that. I think we saw Trump and Xi go back home after the G20. While there wasn't a joint communication, they did go back home and they both tried to spend it domestically. "Hey, we got some things done. There is some progress." We took that as a positive cue. If you look at one silver lining from the G20, I think that's it, that they said "We have to get something done here." They're looking at the markets, both of them. Their respective domestic markets.

BARTIROMO: But you do think we're seeing this rally today because of this new talk last night, right?

BELL: Yes, I definitely think that the rally we're seeing --

BARTIROMO: That's what's pushing --

BELL: -- this morning is because of that.

BARTIROMO: Right now.

BELL: Yes.

BELL: We also have another push for tax reform, Ben. So what about that? I mean House Ways and Means Committee Chairman --

PHILLIPS: I don't think that's what's driving markets today.

BARTIROMO: OK. Because Kevin Brady is retooling this tax cuts 2.0 right now.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: He's trying to secure more Republican votes, the bill delayed several healthcare taxes that allows expecting parents to create 529 plans for their unborn children.

PHILLIPS: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: So, you don't think that has an impact in any way, right?

PHILLIPS: No, I think that the plan he released, I think it was the Wednesday after Thanksgiving or the week after Thanksgiving was more bipartisan-looking and I think that the revisions are more partisan. And so it seems pretty lame ducky some politicking at this point in time.

MCDOWELL: And speaking of politics, I'll throw this in. I'm hearing this more and more from investors. They're really waiting for the Mueller report to come out, and they point to the two months before the Ken Starr report came out in 1998, which was in September of that year, granted that was the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management at that time as well, so it's hard to separate the two, but in the two months, between mid-July and the Starr report coming out in September, the S&P fell almost 20 percent.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: About -- more than 90 percent. Granted the market made back all that loss by the end of November, but this is -- people are standing back and now waiting as more and more filings come out of the Mueller Team, out of the U.S. Attorney in the -- for the Southern District of NEW YORK on Friday, that's becoming a focus as well. And I -- Gary B. talked about it over the weekend.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it's one of three really important things that will probably give us a sense of what's going to happen in 2020.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Number one, who did the Democrats put out there to go against President Trump? Number two, how's the economy doing? We'll see if we are in a growth slowdown come 2020, and number three, the Mueller report.

MCDOWELL: I want to --

BARTIROMO: What comes out of Mueller?

MCDOWELL: I want to add one more thing. I think the markets -- and I know you'll agree with me, are -- you're getting a little bit of a lift moving into the week because we did get an inversion of the yield curve between the two-year and the 10-year to where, you know, if the shorter rates are higher, that indicates the recession it has for the last 50 years, we didn't get that last week, and I think that there was a bit of relief among investors (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Because as it was coming close, the two-year --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- and the 10-year markets were selling off.

MCDOWELL: Right. As narrow as it was since 2007, but we didn't get that inversion and --

BELL: And the reporting on the Fed potentially walking back, maybe taking --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BELL: -- more of a dovish tone obviously played well into that.

BARTIROMO: Right. Do you buy into that? Fed's not going to raise as many as people think right now?

PHILLIPS: I -- yes.

BARTIROMO: Ray Dalio, by the way, told us he's not -- they're not going to be able to do it three times next year.

PHILLIPS: I don't think so. I mean, we look at -- if trade continues like this, that is a drag on growth, and even if it's just discussions, it is dragging growth, it's dragging confidence, so if we see this continue, I don't think the Fed's hiking.

BARTIROMO: Ben, it's good to have you on the show.

PHILLIPS: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Ben Phillips joining us there. Coming up, Macron gives in, the French President pledging tax cuts now, and a minimum wage increase following weeks of dangerous protests where more than a billion dollars of damage was done. Then Google is on the hill today, CEO Sundar Pichai set to answer questions from the House Judiciary Committee on alleged bias against conservatives. We're going to cover that live and we'll talk about it next. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. More drama across the pond after the U.K. Government postponed today's scheduled vote on its plan to leave the European Union. Cheryl Casone with the headlines right now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: So many moving parts to this story, Maria. Good morning to you. Prime Minister Theresa May is now in Brussels after she postponed today's scheduled vote on Britain's plan to leave the E.U. May plans to meet with European leaders in order to signal concessions on the deal, but the E.U. is already ruling out any further negotiations. And May could face a challenge to her leadership for rivals in the Conservative party. Well, Lord of the Rings actor, Andy Serkis, reviving his old Gollum character to poke fun at U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May and her precious Brexit deal, look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDRY SERKIS: They told us, precious, they hates the deal. All of them hates it. They wants a People's vote. People's vote."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Sorry. Serkis released the video over the weekend with the title "Leaked Footage from Inside Number 10 Downing Street." The video has been viewed, as you can imagine, more than a million times, it released ahead of the planned parliamentary vote, which, again, is looking like it's going to be pretty funny. All right.

Let's move to France. Embattled President Emmanuel Macron promising to cut taxes and increase the minimum wage as he addressed the nation last night. His first public comments following four weeks of violent protests over his economic agenda. Macron admitting he is partially responsible for the demonstrations led the by yellow-vest protestors who took to the streets to oppose higher fuel taxes now they're government changes and been improving the economy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, PRESIDENT OF FRANCE (through translator): And I want to see an immediate and real improvement in the salaries, and this is why I'm ordering an end of year bonus for all employees without any tax.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Uh-hmm. Last week, Macron suspended a hike in the fuel tax. Maria, those are your headlines.

BARTIROMO: Yes. A lot of drama coming out. And I think, Dagen, you made the point yesterday, "Well, if you're in Britain, you could look across the channel and thank God you're not in France right now." What were -- what were your thoughts of what we heard last night about --

MCDOWELL: Which they think all the time. I lived in Britain and they don't really love the French. They love the food, but not the people who cook it because they --

LAYFIELD: I think Europe's falling apart. I've heard they've already got the 48 letters signed and that they're really to be delivered at any point. Nobody wants the Prime Minister role right now, but I think that the Brexit ends up being probably a hard Brexit, which, if that happens, I think Italy drops out of the E.U. as well, and the E.U. dissolves.

BARTIROMO: Well, that -- this is a really important point that you're making here. I mean you said Europe is falling apart.

LAYFIELD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And we know what's going on in France, we know the situation in Britain, then there's Italy.

LAYFIELD: That's right.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VCJ-K0C1-F021-6022-00000-00New Trump policy makes it easier for big tech to discriminate, insiders say;'Transparency' rule requires labor department to reveal details of investigations to their targets2019-02-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisUS NEWSVersion:2New Trump policy makes it easier for big tech to discriminate, insiders say'Transparency' rule requires labor department to reveal details of investigations to their targetsSam Levin in Oakland

The Trump administration is making it easier for tech companies to discriminate against workers, with a policy that impedes efforts to close the gender pay gap in Silicon Valley, current and former US labor officials said.

A new US Department of Labor (DoL) "transparency" directive is forcing DoL officials to disclose preliminary details about anti-discrimination investigations to the targets of the inquiries, which, current and former DoL employees say, enables those companies to evade enforcement efforts and conceal potential violations while cases are ongoing. It's as if the FBI or the Internal Revenue Service had to give an advanced heads-up to entities they were investigating, the DoL employees say.

A longtime DoL employee not authorized to speak publicly described the policy as a "giveaway to government contractors", adding that "transparency" was a misnomer: "The objective of this directive is to try to weaken [DoL] enforcement."

The policy was announced in September 2018 by DoL's contract compliance director, Craig Leen, and the acting assistant secretary for policy, Jonathan Berry - both Trump appointees - but prompted opposition from some in the agency. It is one of many examples of the DoL's new leadership eroding existing regulations meant to support workers' rights, said Laura Padin, senior staff attorney with the National Employment Law Project. The Trump administration   suspended an equal pay initiative, moved to   roll back a child labor rule, and has   dismantled anti-discrimination protections for LGBT workers.

"You have an agency that's supposed to be the watchdog, and they are not doing their job," said Patricia Shiu, who served as the DoL's director of federal contract compliance under Obama. "This is what federal contractors want."

Industry groups have long pushed for these kinds of changes that would make it harder for the government to scrutinize their labor practices, said Tia Koonse, legal and policy research manager at the UCLA Labor Center.

The changes could be particularly beneficial for Silicon Valley firms, which make hundreds of millions in taxpayer dollars each yearby providing a range of software products and other services to federal agencies. The new directive effectively helps those tech corporations avoid scrutiny, labor experts warn, despite growing recognition that white men in tech make higher salaries than   women and   minorities doing equivalent work - in   violation of equal pay   laws.

Under the Obama administration, the DoL repeatedly reported findings of pay gaps and other forms of systemic discrimination in Silicon Valley. A number of Silicon Valley companies have faced DoL investigations.

In the department's long-running case against Google, the DoL announced this week that in line with the "transparency" directive, it was dropping an appeal that could have forced Google to hand over specific employee salary data. The DoL in 2017   accused Google of "extreme" discrimination against women across the company. Google denies the allegations.

Leen, the DoL compliance director , defended the decision to dismiss the appeal in the Google case, saying it was "the most effective means of reaching final resolution with Google". Because the DoL had already obtained a trove of records, the case continues and it is unclear how the directive will affect the outcome.

But DoL insiders and former agency leaders say they fearthe "transparency" directive will be most detrimental to new investigations.

The directive is "limiting the tools available to the agency to fulfill its mission", said Janette Wipper, former regional director of the DoL contract compliance division. "This directive doesn't address the interest of employees who work for federal contractors. It's transparency in one direction."

Under federal law, companies that do business with the US government agree to meet specific non-discrimination standards, enact proactive affirmative action plans, and allow the DoL to access salary records. The DoL's compliance investigations are a significant opportunity for regulators to push for pay equality on a large scale. An estimated 25% of US employees work for federal contractors.

The directive is ostensibly aimed at helping government contractors comply with the DoL's anti-discrimination audits by directing investigators to work more "collaboratively" with companies. But it in effect limits the scope of information the DoL can request during an investigation and creates new time constraints for those investigations. Most notably, when the DoL wants to access additional data during its inquiry, the directive stipulates that labor investigators must provide a "summary of any preliminary indicators of discrimination" to the company under investigation.

"I don't see how you can perform a competent investigation about whether there are problems with the pay gap if you don't have the data," said Wendy Musell, a civil rights lawyer and chair of the California Employment Lawyers Association. "This is one of the only mechanisms where we can ensure that our federal taxpayer dollars are not funding discriminatory employment practices."

"The overall message is, 'We know that you're discriminating, and we are content to prevent regulators from catching you,'" said one longtime DoL employee, who was not authorized to speak publicly about the directive.

"It would tell the target of the investigation very early on the theory of the case," said the DoL employee added. "They will be able to game the system."

A national DoL spokesperson said the agency remained "committed to increasing compliance with the law" for contractors, adding: "The transparency directive ensures that contractors are made aware of [DoL]'s indicators of discrimination promptly in order to ensure that such discrimination is remedied sooner ... so that America's workers receive relief as quickly as possible when there are violations."

Since 2017, the DoL's contract compliance program recovered more than $44m from contractors with back pay and other awards for victims of discrimination, the spokesperson added. That includes financial relief for more than 22,000 workers and job applicants, she added.

But Shiu, the former DoL director, said it appeared the department was taking credit for cases launched under the previous administration, and that she expected the new directive would prevent these kinds of payouts moving forward.

The department was misleading the public about the intent of the new policy, she added: "If you don't want to enforce the law, don't enforce the law. But don't pretend you are doing it under the guise of 'transparency'."

urn:contentItem:5XY8-2WG1-JB20-G0B3-00000-00New Union President Under Investigation for Kickbacks; Fox News Poll: Races Tightens Between President Donald Trump and Democrats 2020 Race; Ways to Increase Your Credit Score in 2020; Animal Rights Group PETA Blasting Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez for Buying A Dog Instead Of Rescuing From A Shelter2020-01-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:16ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTFoster Friess; Ted Rossman; Jon Lonski; Rob Smith, Fred Fleitz, Ken MahoneyNEWSFinancial011002cb.231New Union President Under Investigation for Kickbacks; Fox News Poll: Races Tightens Between President Donald Trump and Democrats 2020 Race; Ways to Increase Your Credit Score in 2020; Animal Rights Group PETA Blasting Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez for Buying A Dog Instead Of Rescuing From A ShelterMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Deirdre Bolton

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, January 10th.

Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Jobs in America today. We are 90 minutes away from the December jobs report. Here's what we are expecting, 164,000 jobs added to the economy in the month of December. The unemployment rate holding steady at 3.5 percent. We have full coverage of this all-important read on the American economy. We will identify where the jobs are today.

Markets are higher this morning, pushing toward yet another record as we await the December report. Dow futures up 64, S&P futures up nine, Nasdaq futures up 40.

The Dow looking to cross the 29,000 threshold for the first time ever. Look at that, we're at 28,994 right now on the Dow. Yesterday, the Dow, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 all hit record high closes. Uncharted territory.

Global markets this morning look like this. European indices this morning are higher. As you can see, fractional moves, Brexit, another step closer to reality. Britain's House of Commons approving a bill authorizing the country's departure from the European Union. This puts the U.K. on course for a January 31st exit from the European Union. DAX index in Germany is the best performer this morning in Europe, up 21 points, a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly higher. Take a look. As you can see, the best performer there was Korea. The Kospi index up almost 1 percent.

2020 in focus. President Trump holding his first rally of the year, telling the crowd in Ohio last night he hopes former Vice President Joe Biden will become the Democratic nominee, vowing to bring up Hunter Biden in every single debate, said the president.

Crisis at the border. Apprehensions continuing to decline in December, falling for a seventh consecutive month.

Plus this, TV overload. Over 500 new shows made in 2019, and that number is expected to rise this year. Five hundred original shows.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Moody's Capital Markets chief economist John Lonski is here, Fox Business' Dagen McDowell and Turning Point USA spokesperson, Iraq War veteran, Rob Smith.

Great to have everybody this morning.

ROB SMITH, SPOKESPERSON, TURNING POINT USA: Great to be here.

JOHN LONSKI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S CAPITAL MARKETS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Got a lot to talk about this morning.

And our top story this hour, the Iran plane crash. Iran reportedly inviting Boeing to help investigate this week's deadly Ukrainian International Airways crash that killed 176 people aboard. And now Iran is denying shooting down that passenger jet after the U.S. said that intelligence supports the scenario that they, in fact, did shoot it down. At least 62 victims were from Canada. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau weighed in on the investigation yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JUSTIN TRUDEAU, CANADIAN PRIME MINISTER: This may well have been unintentional. This new information reinforces the need for a thorough investigation into this matter.

Canadians have questions and they deserve answers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is former National Security Council chief of staff, former CIA officer and Center for Security Policy president and CEO Fred Fleitz.

Fred, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

FRED FLEITZ, FORMER NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL CHIEF OF STAFF: Hey, Maria. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: What do you think happened here?

FLEITZ: Well, Maria, it's a terrible tragedy and I think it simply is a sign that when you use terrorism as part of state craft, terrible things are going to happen. This is something that Iran brought upon itself. It was apparently something done by miscalculation. And the Iranian government's going to have to own up for this.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But, I mean, they're denying it. Are we ever going to get to the bottom of it, Fred?

FLEITZ: Well, I mean, this is just the way regimes like this go. They never tell the truth. They'll probably always deny it. But I think the evidence on what happened here is fairly apparent. There's actually video that's out right now of a missile apparently hitting this plane and you can see the explosion in the air. So the Iranian government can deny it as much as it wants. The facts are facts.

BARTIROMO: So -- go ahead, John, did you want to jump in?

LONSKI: Well, you know, my question here would be, the Iranian economy is performing horribly. It's one of the worst economies in the world right now. Supposedly it shrank by nearly 10 percent in 2019, expected to shrink yet again in 2020.

I mean there's got to be some threshold at which the Iranian government has no choice but to try to improve its standing with the international community, hoping to get these very restrictive sanctions eased somehow.

Do you think we're moving close to that point?

FLEITZ: That's an excellent point. President Trump's maximum pressure policy has put enormous pressure on the Iranian economy. And it's not just undermining support for their regime because of economic problems, it's led to anti-Iran protests in Lebanon, in Iraq and even in Syria. And the president's waiting for the time when the Iranian government is ready to do the right thing and start negotiations to end these sanctions, but in the meantime, he's going to keep the pressure up.

SMITH: Hey, Rob Smith here. I have a question.

So, do you think Iran is buying time, making this invitation for others to come help them sort of investigate what's going on here when all of the intelligence tells us what happened.

FLEITZ: I think the Iranian government is in denial. It's playing political games. It never tells the truth. It's always making idle threats against the United States and others. It continues to say it's complying with this nuclear deal, even though there's plenty of evidence it's been cheating on the agreement from the start.

BARTIROMO: Right.

FLEITZ: We just can't believe anything it said.

BARTIROMO: Well, this came up last night. The president holding a rally in Ohio, speaking out about the killing of Iran General Soleimani.

Listen to this. Got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As the leader of Iran's terrorist Quds force, Soleimani spread death, destruction and mayhem across the Middle East and far beyond. He ordered the violent assault on the American embassy in Baghdad. And you saw this was the anti-Benghazi. We got there very, very quickly.

Soleimani was actively planning new attacks and he was looking very seriously at our embassies. And not just the embassy in Baghdad. But we stopped him and we stopped him quickly and we stopped him cold.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And yet, Fred, the -- Nancy Pelosi with her resolution vote last night in terms of limiting the president's powers in terms of dealing with such provocations.

FLEITZ: It's really a shame. I mean politics is supposed to end at water's edge and the president said he did not notify Congress about this sensitive military operation because he was worried about leaks. We have to face the reality that the national security debate has become poisoned by Trump derangement syndrome and, frankly, the real possibility of leaks. And I hate to say that. I know members and staff on the House Intelligence Committee. They really believe that Adam Schiff has been leaking. It's really a sad commentary that the president cannot get congressional buy-in for situations like this, operations like this in advance, but he has to keep the lives of American soldiers in mind. If he thinks Congress is going to leak, they simply don't deserve advanced notification of these operations.

BARTIROMO: This is extraordinary. I mean this is a moment in time when we've got serious situations unfolding and the president cannot trust the Congress not to leak. And they don't trust each other. They're not talking about it.

And, by the way, we haven't even had -- I don't think the Intel Committee has had a meeting, a hearing on Iran at all in the last year. I mean I don't know how many months it's been, but it's all about impeachment.

SMITH: You know, this is very unfortunate, and I think that we're at a moment here where, look, American security and operations and things of this nature, these are things that should be bipartisan. And we're in a point right now where it seems like everything is about political games --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

SMITH: Especially when it comes from the left. And I do not blame them at all for keeping the information about this attack away from the left because I do believe that they would have leaked it.

BARTIROMO: You were nodding when the president was talking just a minute ago --

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: About the anti-Benghazi.

SMITH: It is the anti-Benghazi.

BARTIROMO: You're an Iraq War veteran, Rob.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Tell me why you were nodding.

SMITH: Well, I was nodding because it was just absolutely right. This is the anti-Benghazi. When you look at how quickly and how forcefully America reacted to this attack on the U.S. embassy, which was predicated also by the killing of an American contractor, which was also predicated before that by the killing of hundreds of American soldiers. And when you look at how quick and forceful the response was, it was the anti-Benghazi. We lost not a single American soldier during this entire process.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So where does this go, Fred? What happens now?

FLEITZ: Well, I think the president took the right approach on Soleimani. I believe he's just simply going to stay the course concerning Iran. We have to see what's going to happen in Iraq, because the Iraqi prime minister asked the U.S. overnight to send a delegation to Iraq to discuss the withdrawal of American troops. I don't think that's going to happen. But, frankly, if the Iraqi government doesn't want us there, we should leave. I mean it's an enormous expenditure for our country and we're there to help the people of Iraq. But I don't think that that question has been settled yet.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: However, Fred, that -- because the narrative out of the left was immediately with the killing of a known terrorist, Soleimani, who had killed Americans, 608 American troops just in Iraq alone, the narrative was this is World War III. This is the -- we're going to lead to the loss of life with blood on President Trump's hands.

But, in fact, there's at least an equal likelihood that troops come home, rather than more troops going into the region, right?

FLEITZ: I think that's right. And it's really important to notice that this missile attack conducted by Iran, either it failed because the Iranians fired missiles that were not capable of hitting their targets or they were very accurate missiles that they designed not to hit the targets. And the reason for that is that they did not want to provoke a war and they were worried about how President Trump would respond.

He's a credible leader. He does not want to get into a war. But he will respond overwhelmingly if Americans are killed.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, Fred, we will leave it there.

By the way, just to be clear, the Iranian investigation team says it will first seek to analyze the black boxes but it is willing to hand over the so-called black boxes to another country for analysis. They're talking about U.K., U.S., Ukraine, France, and Canada, to probe the -- what's behind the crash.

MCDOWELL: There are Ukrainian -- there are Ukrainian individuals on the ground going to help with the investigation.

BARTIROMO: Fred, it's good to see you this morning. Thank you.

FLEITZ: Good to be here. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Fred Fleitz joining us there.

A quick break and then we are awaiting the December jobs reporting out in just under an hour and a half. We will have special coverage starting at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. We're identifying where the jobs are, where the wages are moving up the most.

And then production bonanza. Streaming taking content to a whole new level. We have the shocking number of shows produced, created in 2019. It's a big number.

And then watching your wallet. Tips to keep and improve your credit score ahead. Don't miss it. Back in a minute.

But first, border arrests falling. The Trump administration tackling illegal immigration. We are taking a look at that.

Plus, this guy could be arresting you.

(VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. The man behind the Incredible Hulk headed into law enforcement. Details when we come back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Another border wall gets the go-ahead.

Cheryl Casone on headlines now.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well, not without some controversy, Maria. A federal judge ruled in favor of the privately funded wall. Fisher Industries is going to build the barrier on land along the Rio Grande River in Texas. You may remember that Texas sued to stop construction over environment concerns.

And arrests at the border are actually on the decline we've just learned. Customs and Border Protection says more than 40,000 people were taken into custody last month, but that's down 72 percent from the height of the crisis back in May of 2019.

Well, Target's looking to take on Lululemon with a new activewear brand. It's called All In Motion. It's expected to bring in $1 billion in its first year. ROSSMAN: So that is how much credit you're using divided by your total credit limits.

We want you to keep it below 30 percent if you can, below 10 percent would be even better.

In addition, one in five couples ask for donations to their honeymoon funds instead of actual gifts. What do you think?

SMITH: I think --

MCDOWELL: Don't buy the engagement ring and then you can pay for the wedding.

SMITH: I think it's the tackiest thing I've ever heard of. I got married about 2-1/2 years ago, I would not even think about asking people to pay for the wedding.

BARTIROMO: It's unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: Did you have a big wedding?

SMITH: 50 people, so pretty small.

MCDOWELL: Just small.

BARTIROMO: Quick break and then we get the jobs numbers coming out next hour, all hands on deck. Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5WK7-WY21-F03R-N2V2-00000-00New US House Bill Would Ban Big Tech From 'Banking', Fine Facebook's Libra $1 Million Per Day2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:15ZLexisNexisNew US House Bill Would Ban Big Tech From 'Banking', Fine Facebook's Libra $1 Million Per DayZero Hedge

Jul 16, 2019( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1]. View original post here[2]. Shortly before Treasury Secretary Stephen Mnuchin held his crypto-fearmongering press conference, CoinTelegraph's Kollen Post reports [3]that a drafted bill entitled 'Keep Big Tech out of Finance' has surfaced online, allegedly deriving from within the United States House of Representatives Financial Services Committee. The document's metadata dates it July 12. Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act Discussion Draft[4] The bill's provenance is unconfirmed, but crypto news site The Blockquotes[5]an inside source as saying it is with the Financial Services Committee. The document reads:'A large platform utility may not establish, maintain, or operate a digital asset that is intended to be widely used as medium of exchange, unit of account, store of value, or any other similar function, as defined by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.'The alleged bill goes on to define 'a large platform utility' as a tech company that earns annual global revenues in excess of $25 billion. Given that Libra is scheduled for hearings before the Senate Banking Committee onJuly 16and with the House Financial Services Committee onJuly 17, this bill seems designed to preempt congressional authority to take decisive action on the issue of Libra.

https://www.zerohedge.com/s3/files/inline-images/2019-07-15_6-28-41.jpg?itok=pMa6YqMCimage courtesy of CoinTelegraph[6] In fact, as Reuters reports[7], the legislation proposes to impose a $1 million fine daily upon any firm that violates its proposed rules. Libra has attracted commentary and criticism from many corners. Chair of the Financial Services Committee Maxine Waters initiated the congressional hearings on Libra on June 18 by calling for a moratorium on the project. As Cointelegraphreported[8]at the time, Representative Waters wrote:'Given the company's troubled past, I am requesting that Facebook agree to a moratorium on any movement forward on developing a cryptocurrency until Congress and regulators have the opportunity to examine these issues and take action'The night of July 11, US President Donald Trumptweeted[9]similar concerns about the lawfulness of crypto usage, expressing opposition to Libra, Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies as a whole, instead promoting the continued dominance of the U.S. dollar. Reuters [10]nonetheless anticipates that 'pro-innovation' Republicans will put their muscle behind blocking such a move, and that the bill could face yet steeper resistance should it pass the lower chamber and be debated in the U.S. Senate.
